document_summary: The 2026 Pesticide General Permit (PGP) authorizes certain point-source discharges from pesticide applications to U.S. waters (effective Oct 31, 2026–Oct 30, 2031) and sets technology- and water-quality-based limits, monitoring, corrective-action, recordkeeping, and reporting requirements for Applicators and Decision‑makers. Decision‑makers meeting specified thresholds must submit a timely Notice of Intent (NOI) via EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool (or a paper waiver), include Pesticide Discharge Management Plans (PDMPs) for large entities, and demonstrate Endangered Species Act eligibility using EPA’s geospatial tool or existing Section 7/10 consultations; Notices of Termination (NOTs) and annual reports follow similar electronic‑first filing rules. The permit requires visual and additional monitoring as needed, 24‑hour adverse‑incident notification to EPA (with 30‑day written reports) and spill reporting to the National Response Center, mandates PDMP content and updates, and prescribes corrective‑action timelines and retention of records for at least three years. Appendix and Part 9 provisions add extensive state, territorial, and tribal-specific conditions (notably New Mexico antidegradation and Pueblo notice rules and Region 10/Washington species, timing, and littoral‑zone restrictions), provide forms/addresses for filings, and list regional EPA contacts and permitted active ingredients or use restrictions.

section_summaries.9.0 Permit Conditions Applicable Within: All NOIs/NOTs, reports, analytical data and related correspondence must be sent concurrently to the Pueblo of Isleta Environment Department (PO Box 1270, Isleta NM 87022; WQCO@isletapueblo.com) by electronic mail and U.S. First Class Mail; electronic copies are also required for permit actions occurring within 8 river miles upstream of the Pueblo boundary. Restricted-use pesticides are prohibited within Pueblo lands, and the Pueblo may impose more stringent action thresholds to protect surface waters, pollinators, and other resources, as authorized by the Pueblo of Isleta Surface Water Quality Standards and the Pueblo’s antidegradation policy.

Decision-makers covered by the PGP must electronically send NOIs to the Pueblo of Sandia concurrently with EPA (and NOTs within three business days after EPA acceptance) to Greg Kaufman and Cynthia King, and must submit any required Pesticide Discharge Management Plan (PDMP) to the same contacts 10 days before application. These notifications enable the Pueblo to evaluate site-specific compliance with its Water Quality Standards (including Total DDT/metabolites and pesticide-related toxic substance limits); authority cited: Pueblo of Sandia Water Quality Standards (2023).

Footnotes clarify that numeric human health criteria assume consumption of fish (not regular water ingestion), define shorthand (hd=hardness, ln=natural log, -- = no criterion), and use MCLs/background when no fish-based criterion exists; carcinogen criteria reflect a 1×10^-6 risk. EPA toxic substance criteria are incorporated through triennial review, site-specific criterion modifications can be adopted after public participation and EPA approval, and pesticides/PCBs require routine sediment and tissue analysis with investigations triggered when fish tissue exceeds FDA Action Limits.
Under 20.6.4.7(S)(5) NMAC (Pueblo of Taos), there are no additional Notice of Intent (NOI) requirements beyond the general permit conditions.

Decision-makers required under PGP Part 1.2 must send a copy of their Notice of Intent (NOI) to the Santa Clara Pueblo Environmental Director within 3 days of EPA submittal and must provide the Notice of Termination (NOT) within 3 days of EPA acceptance; the contact is dnoc@santaclarapueblo.org. Those required under PGP Part 5.0 must also submit an electronic copy of the Pesticide Discharge Management Plan (PDMP) to the same address when the NOI is submitted; these requirements ensure compliance with the Santa Clara Pueblo Water Quality Code and tribal resource protection.

Provides the mailing address to submit the Notice of Intent (NOI) for coverage under the Pesticide General Permit (PGP): U.S. EPA, Office of Water, Water Permits Division, Mail Code 4203M, ATTN: NPDES Pesticides, 1200 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington, DC 20460.

Provides the overnight/express delivery address for filing a paper Notice of Intent to EPA’s NPDES Pesticides (EPA East Building, Room 7420, 1201 Constitution Ave NW, Washington, DC 20004), directs users to the EPA pesticide permitting webpage and the NPDES eReporting help desk (phone and email) for questions, and states that paper NOIs must be original signed documents (no copies or faxes) and must include any required Pesticide Discharge Management Plan (PDMP).

Provides the United States Mail address for filing a paper Notice of Termination (NOT) under the Pesticide General Permit when an electronic submission waiver is approved: EPA Office of Water, Water Permits Division, Mail Code 4203M, ATTN: NPDES Pesticides, 1200 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20460.

Send paper Notices of Termination via overnight/express delivery to the EPA Office of Water, Water Permits Division (ATTN: NPDES Pesticides) at EPA East Building - Room 7420, 1201 Constitution Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20004. Submit the original form with an ink signature—do not send copies and faxed copies are not accepted.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > **A: Provides the mailing address and recipient details for filing the paper annual report (electronic submission waiver) to the U.S. EPA: Office of Water, Water Permits Division, Mail Code 4203M, ATTN: NPDES Pesticides, 1200 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington, DC 20460. Appears under the Annual Report Preparer section, which should be completed if someone other than the certifier prepared the report.

Provides the overnight/express delivery address for EPA Office of Water (ATTN: NPDES Pesticides) in Washington, DC, includes the NPDES pesticide permitting webpage and NPDES eReporting help desk phone/email for questions, and instructs that paper annual reports must be the original with an ink signature (no copies or faxes accepted).
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > App: Statement 1 requires the applicant to confirm a prior ESA Section 7 consultation fully covers direct and indirect effects of proposed discharges and related activities in the Project Action Area. The consultative outcome must be either a biological opinion (FWS and/or NMFS) finding no jeopardy/no adverse modification with Reasonable and Prudent Measures implemented, or written concurrence (FWS and/or NMFS) that the actions are not likely to adversely affect listed species or critical habitat.

Requires a completed ESA Section 7(a)(2) consultation that fully covers discharge effects and confirmation that both FWS and NMFS resources were considered using the EPA geospatial mapping tool. You must provide responses to D1–D6 (federal action agency, Service field/regional offices, FWS/NMFS consultation or project codes and numbers, consultation completion dates, and attach correspondence/biological/conference opinions). If you can supply D1–D6 and attachments, you may certify Criterion D on the NOI; if not, proceed to Step 4. If filing a paper NOI under a waiver, include the map/list and this worksheet with the submission.
section_summaries.9.0 Permit Conditions Applicable Within: This section lists NOI/NOT and PDMP notification and reporting requirements for projects in Indian Country within New Mexico (excluding Navajo and Ute Mountain Reservations), including specific procedures and contacts for Ohkay Owingeh, Pueblo of Isleta, Pueblo of Sandia, Pueblo of Taos (no additional NOI requirements), and Santa Clara Pueblo. It cites 20.6.4.7(S)(5) NMAC (including the state definition of “surface waters of the state”) and highlights timing (typically copies to tribal environmental offices within three business days), pesticide restrictions/thresholds, and sediment/tissue monitoring triggers and criteria footnotes relevant to permit compliance.

For the Pueblo of Pojoaque, there are no additional Notice of Intent requirements beyond the standard permit conditions. Users searching for state- or tribe-specific NOI guidance for Pojoaque will find there are no extra regulatory citations or guidance in this section.

Decision-makers must send certified NOIs (and NOI modifications/NOTs) to the Picuris Pueblo Governor and Environmental Department within two business days of EPA submission (addresses provided). PDMPs must be emailed to environment@picurispueblo.org before or with the NOI; annual reports and DMRs must be sent to the Tribe within three business days of EPA submission. Operators must notify the Picuris Pueblo Environmental Department within 10 days of any bypass or upset. These requirements ensure Tribal review and compliance with Picuris Pueblo water quality standards.

Decision-makers must submit NOIs to EPA and simultaneously provide copies to the Pueblo of Santa Ana (Governor Myron Armijo) and the Pueblo Department of Natural Resources (Tammy Montoya, Water Resources Division Manager, 02 Dove Road, Santa Ana Pueblo, NM 87004; tammy.montoya@santaana-nsn.gov). PDMPs, annual reports, NOTs, associated analytical data and written reports for actions on Pueblo lands or within five river miles of the Pueblo’s northern boundary must be sent to the Pueblo at the same time as EPA (NOTs and reports within three business days of EPA submittal/acceptance); discharges are not authorized until an accurate, complete NOI is provided and the Pueblo may request additional information or delay/deny coverage.

Decision-makers must provide the Pueblo of San Felipe Natural Resources Director an electronic copy of any NOI and any NOT within 3 days of submitting the NOI to EPA or receiving EPA confirmation of NOT acceptance (email: pstout@sfpueblo.com). Entities required to prepare a Pesticide Discharge Management Plan (PDMP) must also submit an electronic copy to the Director at the same time the NOI is submitted; these requirements ensure compliance with water quality standards and protect tribal resources.

This section lists the approved active ingredients for aquatic mosquito control under EPA Region 10 water-quality permit conditions, naming 16 specific agents such as Bacillus sphaericus (H-5a5b), Bti, malathion, methoprene, monomolecular surface films, paraffinic white mineral oil, spinosad, naled, natural pyrethrins/pyrethroids (e.g., permethrin, deltamethrin), and the synergist piperonyl butoxide. Useful for queries about which mosquito-control chemicals are permitted in Region 10.

Project proponents must ensure larvicide or adulticide applications do not permanently harm endangered, threatened, sensitive, or candidate species by consulting and complying with the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW) Areas of Restricted Larvicide and Adulticide Use map before any mosquito control treatments. Areas within the proponent’s jurisdiction are subject to WDFW restrictions and protections for listed species and priority habitats.

Specifies restrictions on mosquito control chemicals: malathion and naled are prohibited in identified vulnerable-species areas, methoprene briquettes are banned in marine/estuarine sites, and malathion may only be used for larval control when resistance is documented and after consultation with WDFW. Requires use of ULV equipment for adulticides if available, provides WDFW contact/map for area-specific restrictions, and cites RCW/WAC authorities and AKART as justification.

Sets maximum percentages of a water body’s littoral zone that may be treated with herbicides by size (≤15 acres: 75%; >15–50 acres: 60%; >50–500 acres: 50%; >500 acres: 30%). The treatment area must remain the same for the permit term, and untreated littoral areas must retain native vegetation from the shore to the littoral edge. Exceptions: 100% treatment allowed in rights-of-way, levees and dikes; shorelines/roadsides/ditches limited to 40% native-vegetation treatment but 100% allowed for noxious/quarantine weeds. Permits can restrict where chemicals are applied but cannot control downstream dispersion.

Allows targeted algaecide use on filamentous green algae (limited to littoral zone) and permits whole- or partial-waterbody treatments for cyanobacteria/toxic algae, but requires pre- and post-treatment dissolved oxygen monitoring (pre ~24 hours, post no more than 0.2 mg/L drop from pre-treatment). If DO monitoring is infeasible or a DO crash is likely, alternatives are limited to phosphorus sequestration products or treating up to one-third of the lake per week. Measures are justified by Washington AKART and water quality statutes/regulations (specified RCW/WAC citations).

Project proponents must consult WDFW Fish Program (FISHPGM@dfw.wa.gov) before conducting rotenone treatments and must follow the most recent Planning and Standard Operating Procedures for Use of Rotenone in Fish Management (Rotenone SOP Manual). See section 8 for water-rights and replacement-water requirements; restrictions are imposed to meet AKART and state water quality standards, with specific RCW and WAC citations listed.

If the default timing window won’t allow adequate treatment, contact the regional WDFW biologist (see the WDFW Areas of Responsibility map tool) to develop a modified timing window. Specific pesticides subject to WDFW timing windows include 2,4‑D (amine and ester), carfentrazone‑ethyl, approved chelated copper compounds, chlorine, diquat, endothall (mono and dipotassium salts), flumioxazin, potassium permanganate, and rotenone; for other approved chemicals check the map for non‑fish priority species windows. For irrigation canal systems, WDFW timing windows apply only to endothall mono salt. Ecology must follow WDFW mandates to protect sensitive species (see RCW 77.15.120; RCW 77.15.130(1); RCW 77.04.012; WAC 173‑201A‑020).

Provides instructions for filing an appeal with the Pollution Control Hearings Board (PCHB) — includes the current filing webpage (https://eluho.wa.gov/) and phone number ((360) 664-9160) — and gives the required service address for the Washington Department of Ecology (Attn: Appeals Processing Desk, 300 Desmond Drive SE, Lacey, WA 98503).

Lists the mailing address and email for submitting appeals under the 'Your right to appeal' notification requirements for EPA Region 10: Department of Ecology, Attn: Appeals Processing Desk, PO Box 47608, Olympia, WA 98504-7608; E‑Mail: ecologyappeals@ecy.wa.gov.

This subsection collects the NOI preparer’s contact information when the preparer is different from the certifier, requiring preparer name, organization, phone number (and extension), date, and email address.

Operators meeting Part 1.1 eligibility and Decision-makers identified in Table 1-1 must submit a complete NOI for discharges covered by the PGP, including any discharge-related activities overlapping FWS/NMFS listed resources (see Appendix I for ESA criteria). Specific requirements include mandatory NOIs for discharges to Tier 3 (Outstanding National Resource) waters and for federal/state agencies responsible for pest control; local governments or entities exceeding 6,400 acres of treatment in a year also must file. One NOI may cover multiple management areas but cannot include more than one state per form.

Do not file an NOI until you have obtained and read the permit and completed required materials (ESA eligibility worksheet and Pesticide Discharge Management Plan) except where PDMP is waived for Declared Pest Emergency Situations or certain Decision‑makers; a paper NOI requires regional EPA approval. NOIs for discharges after Oct 31, 2026 must be submitted under the 2026 PGP; generally submit at least 30 days before anticipated discharge (15 days for declared emergencies) and coverage is effective no earlier than 30 days after EPA posts receipt unless an emergency allows immediate coverage with prior FWS/NMFS coordination.

Decision-makers must submit NOIs through EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool (NeT) unless granted an Electronic Submission Waiver; EPA posts all NOIs online and late NOIs are accepted but authorization is not retroactive. If waived, paper NOIs (with original signatures and any required Pesticide Discharge Management Plan) must be mailed to the EPA Water Permits Division address or sent via overnight to the EPA East Building address; see the EPA pesticide permitting webpage, Part 8 regional contacts, or the NeT help desk for questions.

Provides step-by-step instructions for completing the Appendix D Notice of Intent (NOI) for coverage under the Pesticide General Permit for discharges from pesticide applications: type or print in uppercase, complete every question, make a photocopy for your records, and mail the original to the EPA address shown. Notes that the paper form can also serve as a checklist when filing the NOI electronically via EPA's NPDES eReporting Tool (NeT).

Indicate whether this NOI is a first-time request for coverage or a change to an existing NOI. For first-time submissions, check the first-time box and consult Table 1-2 for submittal deadlines and authorization dates; for changes, check the change box, provide the NPDES permit tracking number from EPA’s NeT, consult Table 1-3 for change procedures, and update Section B (operator name and mailing address) and any modified fields.

Section B requires the legal name of the Decision-maker (the Operator controlling pesticide application decisions), the Operator type (with optional six-digit NAICS code), whether the Operator is a "large entity" (triggering a Pesticide Discharge Management Plan and annual reporting), the single state where pest management areas are located (one NOI per state), and full contact details (mailing address, phone, optional fax, contact name, and email).

Section C requires one completed form per pest management area with the area name and a map or WGS84 decimal-degree coordinates, and the applicant must indicate whether the area is on Indian Country or federal land. Provide mailing/contact details, select applicable pesticide use patterns, and state whether permit coverage is for all waters or specific waters (including Tier 3) with an attached rationale for Tier 3 discharges. Applicants must also verify and document whether target waters are impaired for planned pesticide active ingredients or degradates if coverage to impaired waters is requested.

Section D requires applicants to demonstrate, for each pest management area, that pesticide discharges will not adversely affect federally listed species or critical habitat by meeting one or more ESA eligibility criteria (A–G) and providing supporting documentation. Applicants must submit a Project Action Area map and species overlap list (generated within 90 days via EPA’s geospatial tool); if asserting Criteria F or G they must supply detailed pesticide/application data and analyses; procedures for emergency coordination and EPA/FWS/NMFS review timelines (authorization in 10–30 days, and presumed authorization after 30 days for Criteria C/D/E) are specified.

Section E requires applicants to indicate which supporting documents they are submitting with their NOI for coverage under the PGP. If an attached document is not listed among the options, applicants must select 'Other' and provide a brief description of that document.

Requires the certifier’s printed name, title, signature, and date (unsigned/undated forms rejected) and cites 40 CFR 122.41(k). Specifies who may sign: responsible corporate officer or authorized manager for corporations, general partner or proprietor for partnerships/sole proprietorships, and principal executive or ranking elected official for public entities. Warns of severe penalties for false information and instructs that if someone other than the certifier prepared the NOI, their name, organization, phone, and email must be provided.

Provides the Paperwork Reduction Act notice: the estimated public reporting/recordkeeping burden is 2.5 hours (150 minutes) per response, and comments on the need, burden estimates, or ways to minimize respondent burden should be sent to the Director, Collection Strategies Division, U.S. EPA (include the OMB control number). It explicitly instructs not to send the completed NOI form to that address.

Operators required to submit a Notice of Intent (NOI) must submit a Notice of Termination (NOT) to end coverage under the PGP, except when EPA directs the Operator to apply for an individual or alternative general permit (coverage then terminates automatically). Dischargers automatically covered or who permanently cease discharge are also automatically terminated per permit criteria. Only certain Operators who are Decision-makers must submit NOIs; NOIs filed under the 2021 PGP automatically terminate at 11:59 p.m. on October 30, 2026, and Decision-makers must file a new NOI for the 2026 PGP. For questions or form help, see the EPA pesticide permitting page or contact the NPDES eReporting help desk.

Operators must file the NOT within 30 days after one or more conditions in Part 1.2.5.2 are met. Use of the paper NOT form is allowed only if the EPA Regional Office grants an electronic submission waiver; when approved, the operator must record the waiver type, the EPA staff person who granted it, and the approval date.

Operators must file the Notice of Termination (NOT) via EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool (NeT) unless granted an Electronic Submission Waiver (noted at top of the NOT form); filing electronically is fastest. If waived, submit the paper NOT to the EPA Office of Water at the specified US Mail or overnight/express addresses, include the original ink-signed form, and do not send copies or faxes; see Part 8 for EPA regional contacts.

Directions require typing or printing in uppercase and completing all questions, making a photocopy for your records before mailing the original to the listed address. The paper form can also serve as a checklist for filing the Notice of Termination electronically via EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool (NeT).

Instructions for Section A require entering the existing NPDES Permit Tracking Number (findable via EPA’s NeT), and selecting one of three reasons for submitting a Notice of Termination: (a) ceased all pesticide discharges for the permit term, (b) obtained individual or alternative NPDES permit coverage, or (c) transferred operator responsibility—if (c), provide the transfer date and the new operator’s name and contact information.

Section B requires the Operator’s full legal name (the decision-maker for the pesticide application), the Operator’s mailing address and telephone number for correspondence, and a contact person’s full legal name and email address for NOT communications related to terminating PGP coverage (when using the paper submission waiver).

Explains the NOT certification: the certifier must sign, date, and provide full legal name, title and email to confirm termination of pesticide discharge authorization; specifies who may sign on behalf of corporations, partnerships/sole proprietorships, and public entities; warns that unsigned/undated forms prevent termination and that false statements carry severe penalties; if a preparer completed the NOT, include their contact details.

This Paperwork Reduction Act notice estimates the public reporting burden for the NOT at 0.5 hours (30 minutes) per response and invites comments on the necessity, accuracy, and burden-minimizing methods. Send comments (including the OMB control number) to the Director, Collection Strategies Division, U.S. EPA, 1200 Pennsylvania Ave., NW, Washington, D.C. 20460, but do not send completed NOT forms to that address.

Small-entity Operators who are Decision-makers required to submit a Notice of Intent (NOI) may complete the PDEW to satisfy PGP Part 7.3. A pest management area can be large or specific and may contain one or more treatment areas; Operators must retain PDEW information for each treatment area but may use one worksheet to document multiple treatment areas with the same or similar pests.

Operators must complete Section B of the PDEW before any pesticide application and complete Section C (except application end date and total quantity) as soon as possible but no later than 14 days after the first application; the application end date and total quantity must be submitted as soon as possible but no later than 14 days after the project’s pesticide application is finished. Operators must retain the worksheet for at least 3 years from permit coverage or termination and provide it to EPA or an authorized representative on request.

This section provides instructions for completing the EPA Pesticide Discharge Evaluation Worksheet (PDEW) for the Pesticide General Permit (PGP), emphasizing that entries should be typed or printed in uppercase and that all questions must be completed. It guides applicants on proper form-filling to document pesticide discharge information necessary for permit compliance.

Section A collects general identification and location details for each pest management area on the PDEW: operator legal name and NPDES tracking number, person completing the form, pest management area number and name, pesticide use pattern(s), and for each treatment area a brief description, size (acres or linear feet), location, and the name/location of any waters of the United States receiving discharges.

Section B (Pest Evaluation) of the PDEW asks applicants to identify target pest(s), explain why control is needed, and describe any pest management measures implemented before pesticide application (such as physical removal, habitat modification, or trapping). This information supports justification for pesticide use and documents integrated pest management actions.

Section C requires recording the applicator’s company/contact, start and end dates of the application, each pesticide product used with EPA registration numbers, quantities applied, and application methods. It also requires documenting whether visual monitoring was performed during and after application (including date, time, and location), explaining why monitoring was not done if applicable, and describing any adverse effects observed.

Requires the certifier’s printed name, title, signature, and date (unsigned/undated forms are not accepted) and cites 40 CFR 122.41(k); false statements carry severe federal penalties. Specifies who may sign: responsible corporate officers or qualified managers for corporations, general partners or proprietors for partnerships/sole proprietorships, and principal executives or ranking elected officials for public entities; if a consultant prepared the PDEW, include the preparer’s name, organization, phone, and email.

This notice estimates the public reporting and recordkeeping burden for the Pesticide Discharge Evaluation Worksheet at about 1 hour per response. It instructs readers to send comments on the need for the information, burden accuracy, and methods to minimize burden (including automated collection techniques) to the Director, Collection Strategies Division, U.S. EPA at the provided Washington, D.C. address and to include the OMB control number; it also warns not to mail completed PDEWs to that address.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > **A: Operators who are Decision‑makers required to submit a Notice of Intent (NOI)—including those meeting the “large entity” definition in Appendix A or whose application causes discharges to U.S. waters or may expose FWS/NMFS listed resources—must submit an annual report to EPA each calendar year. Once you are required to file for one year, you must continue filing every subsequent permit year even if no discharges occur, per Parts 7.6 and 7.7 of the PGP.

Annual reports are due by February 15 for pesticide activities during the prior calendar year. If an NOI is required by exceeding an annual treatment-area threshold, the report must cover that calendar year, with special rules for the first partial year after exceeding the threshold (if first exceeded after Dec 1, you won’t file a separate report for that partial year but the first subsequent annual report must include its activities). If permit coverage is terminated, submit an annual report covering activities up to the termination date, due by the next February 15.

Operators must use EPA’s NetT to submit the Annual Report unless granted an electronic submission waiver; if waived, submit a paper report to the specified EPA Office of Water mailing or overnight/express addresses. Paper reports must be originals with an ink signature, the Annual Report Preparer section must be completed if someone other than the certifier prepared the report, and NPDES eReporting helpdesk/contact info is provided for questions.

Section A instructs users to enter their NOI-assigned permit tracking number (findable via EPA NetT), provide the full legal name of the Decision-maker (an Operator with authority over pesticide application decisions), list the Operator’s address and phone/fax, and give the full legal name, title, and email of the Annual Report contact person.

Record whether an adverse incident occurred for each permitted pest management area and, if so, provide the area name, incident date(s), EPA notification date/time/person/instructions (per Part 6.4 and 6.4.1.1), the date the 30‑day written report was submitted (Part 6.4.2), and a description and rationale for corrective actions taken. If no adverse incidents occurred, proceed to Section C; use additional pages for multiple incident dates.

Section C must be completed for each pest management area (matching the NOI) and begins by indicating whether any discharge from pest control activities occurred this year (checking “no” completes the section). It requires the pesticide use pattern and a detailed treatment-area description — including a geospatial map, size (acres/linear feet), receiving waters, target pests, and any discharges affecting FWS/NMFS listed resources with dates — plus records or explanations for visual monitoring during and after application, applicator contact information (or reference to Section A), whether the activity was addressed in the PDMP before application, and the total amount applied.

The certifier must print their name and title, sign and date the annual report — unsigned or undated forms are not accepted — and the signature must be by an authorized official per 40 CFR 122.41(k) (specified corporate officers or qualified managers for corporations; general partner/proprietor for partnerships/sole proprietorships; principal executive or ranking elected official for public facilities). If someone else prepared the report, include the preparer’s name, organization, phone number, and email address.

This section contains the Paperwork Reduction Act notice for the annual report form and states the estimated public reporting and recordkeeping burden is 8 hours (480 minutes) per response. Users searching for form completion time, reporting burden, or PRA details should consult this notice.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > UNI: Section collects the caller’s contact details as part of the 24-hour adverse incident notification for the PGP 30-day report—specifically fields for the caller’s name and telephone number (including extension). This identifies who reported the incident for follow-up and recordkeeping.

This subsection of the 30-day adverse incident written report captures operator contact details collected from the 24-hour adverse incident notification, including operator name and full mailing address (street, city, state, ZIP+4), and requests the NOI/NPDES permit tracking number (enter “NA” if not applicable).

Fields to record an alternate contact person for the 24-hour adverse incident notification, including the contact's name and full telephone number with extension. Appears in the PGP annual report template under information from the 24-hour notification.

This field requests a concise narrative of how and when the Operator first became aware of the adverse incident, including the date and time, the source or manner of discovery (e.g., visual observation, public complaint, monitoring data, contractor or third‑party report), who reported it, and any immediate notifications or logs created.

Section B of the 30-day adverse incident written report for the Pesticide General Permit collects: the location of the adverse incident; a description of the incident and pesticide product(s) used (including EPA registration number); steps taken or planned to remedy/clean up adverse effects; and identification and notification details for any other authorized Operators involved.

All Operators who observe or learn of a reportable adverse incident under Part 6.4 must submit a 30‑day adverse incident report. EPA recommends documenting incidents even if not reportable; an adverse incident involves likely exposure to pesticide residue and a toxic/adverse effect to a person or non‑target organism, and if multiple Operators are authorized, one Operator’s report satisfies the requirement provided copies are given to the others within 30 days.

Operators must provide a written report of any reportable adverse incidents to the appropriate EPA Regional office and the state lead pesticide regulatory agency within 30 days of the incident, pursuant to Part 6.4.1.1 of the Pesticide General Permit.

Operators must notify the EPA Incident Reporting Contact within 24 hours and submit a written adverse-incident report to the appropriate EPA Regional Office (address in Part 8 of the permit) and the state pesticide lead agency. If the incident may affect federally listed threatened or endangered species or critical habitat, immediately notify NMFS for marine/anadromous species or the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service for terrestrial/freshwater species; contact links are provided on the EPA and service websites.

Operators must submit the 30-day Adverse Incident Written Report under the PGP if the incident is reportable (indicate yes or no on the form; no further action if no). Reporting is not required when the incident is unrelated to pesticide toxic effects/exposure, when EPA has waived reporting, when notification is clearly erroneous, or when the incident affects pests similar to labeled target pests (except as required for threatened/endangered species or critical habitat).

This section lists the specific fields pulled from the 24‑hour adverse-incident and threatened/endangered-species notifications that must be included in the 30-day report: caller and Operator contact details (and alternate contact), NPDES/NeT tracking number (or NA), how/when the Operator learned of the event, incident location, detailed description of the incident including affected non‑target organisms and EPA pesticide registration numbers, steps taken to remedy or clean up, and notification of any other permitted Operators.

Section C requires entering the date and time EPA was contacted about the adverse incident, the legal name and title of the EPA person contacted, and a description of any instructions or guidance provided by that EPA contact for the 30‑day PGP adverse incident report.

Lists the specific information required in the 30‑day adverse incident report: incident location and water appearance, affected species and counts, size/scope of impacted area, and habitat/ambient water conditions. Also requires pesticide details (application rate, intended use site, method, product name and EPA registration number), any laboratory tests and result timelines (results must be summarized within 5 days of availability), and planned actions to prevent recurrence.

This section requires the certifier to print their name and title, sign and date the 30-day Adverse Incident Report (unsigned/undated forms are rejected) and references 40 CFR 122.41(k). It specifies who may sign on behalf of different entity types (responsible corporate officer or authorized manager for corporations; general partner or proprietor for partnerships/sole proprietorships; principal executive or ranking elected official for public entities), warns of penalties for false statements, and requires contact details and the preparation date if someone other than the certifier prepared the report.

This notice states the Paperwork Reduction Act burden for the 30-day Adverse Incident Report is estimated at 4 hours per response and invites comments on the information collection and burden estimates. Send comments (including the OMB control number) to the Director, Collection Strategies Division, U.S. EPA, 1200 Pennsylvania Ave. NW, Washington, DC 20460, and do not send completed Adverse Incident Reports to that address.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > App: Use EPA’s geospatial mapping tool (output within 90 days) to confirm whether FWS and/or NMFS Listed Resources of Concern are present in the Project Action Area; check the appropriate confirmation boxes to certify Criterion A eligibility. If no listed resources are present, submit the map and generated list with the NOI (or keep documentation if an NOI is not otherwise required); if resources are present, proceed to Step 3 (or Step 6 for a Declared Pest Emergency). Paper-NOI waivers must include the map, list, and worksheet.

This section indicates Criterion B is intentionally left blank and provides no eligibility requirements; users should skip ahead to Step 3 of the PGP Eligibility Worksheet for Threatened and Endangered Species Protection.

To qualify under Criterion C you must already hold an ESA Section 10(a)(1) permit that specifically authorizes and covers the effects of your discharges and related activities on all FWS and/or NMFS Listed Resources of Concern in your Project Action Area (as confirmed using the Step 1 geospatial tool). You must provide the map and species list from Step 1, identify which Service issued the permit, the field/regional office, permit/tracking number(s) and date(s), and attach correspondence or a copy of the Section 10 permit with your NOI; if you cannot provide these items (C1–C6), you are not eligible under Criterion C and must proceed to Criterion D.

Criterion D requires a prior ESA Section 7 consultation that fully covers direct and indirect effects of the proposed discharges and related activities in the Project Action Area and concluded with FWS/NMFS written concurrence or a biological opinion finding no jeopardy/no adverse modification. Applicants must confirm Step 1 and Statements 1–2 are true and provide supporting information D1–D6 (agency/office, consultation IDs, dates, and attachments). If consultation reinitiation under 50 C.F.R. §402.16 is pending, you are not eligible; if you cannot supply D1–D6 and attachments, proceed to Step 4 (or include materials with a paper NOI).

This section requires documented coordination with FWS and/or NMFS confirming planned discharges and related activities are not likely to cause short- or long-term adverse effects to listed resources. Applicants must provide the EPA geospatial map and species list used, indicate which Service(s) participated, identify the field/regional office(s), record the coordination conclusion dates, and agree to implement any Service-specified conditions or measures.

Explains how to determine eligibility under ESA Criterion F by assessing whether pesticide discharges will cause short- or long-term adverse effects to FWS/NMFS-listed species or designated critical habitat, advising contact with the appropriate Service for help. To qualify you must self-certify for each listed species that no adverse effects are likely, identify and implement avoidance measures (e.g., BMPs, timing, area avoidance) before submitting the NOI, provide responses to F1–F7 and mapping output (for paper NOIs); inability to answer F1–F7 makes you ineligible and requires re-evaluation or pursuing other criteria/steps.

Pesticide discharges in response to a Declared Pest Emergency may qualify under Criterion G only after prompt coordination with FWS and/or NMFS via email that includes contacts, a project description, a geospatial Project Action Area map, and a list (or confirmation of absence) of listed resources; Service avoidance recommendations must be implemented and written confirmation provided. If eligible, file an NOI within 15 days of discharge (30 days if no listed resources), include responses to G1–G7 as supporting documentation, and restart coordination if proposed discharges change.
section_summaries.Appendices > 1.1 Eligibility > 1.1.2 Lim: Operators are not eligible for permit coverage for pesticide discharges to waters listed as impaired for an active ingredient or a degradate of that pesticide. "Impaired waters" are those identified under CWA Section 303(d), including waters with or without EPA-approved/established TMDLs (list at https://www.epa.gov/tmdl/); operators may submit evidence per Table 1-2 in Part 1.2.3 to request coverage if the water is no longer impaired.

Operators are not eligible for permit coverage for discharges to waters designated Tier 3 (Outstanding National Resource Waters) under 40 CFR 131.12(a)(3). The only exception is for pesticide applications intended to restore/maintain water quality or protect public health/environment that do not degrade water quality or cause only short-term/temporary degradation; a list of Tier 3 waters is available on EPA’s website.

Discharges are ineligible for this permit if they are already covered by another NPDES permit or if they were part of a permit that EPA has denied, terminated, or revoked — or is in the process of doing so — within the past five years. The five‑year restriction does not apply to routine permit reissuance every five years.

Permit coverage applies only to discharges meeting one of seven ESA eligibility criteria (A–G) and requires use of EPA’s geospatial mapping tool to identify FWS/NMFS listed species or critical habitat in the Project Action Area. Criteria C and D rely on prior Section 10 permits or Section 7 consultations, Criterion G requires coordination/notification to the Services, and Decision-makers must include specific supporting documentation with the NOI (see Appendix D and Appendix I) verifying species/habitat assessments and Service notifications.
section_summaries.6.0 Corrective Action > 6.4 Adverse Inci: Operators must telephone the EPA Incident Reporting Contact within 24 hours of becoming aware of any adverse incident potentially caused by a pesticide discharge and provide specified details (caller info, operator name/address, NOI NPDES tracking number if applicable, contact person, how/when discovered, location, description of incident and affected non-target organisms, pesticide product(s) with EPA reg. number, corrective actions, and identities of other authorized operators). If notification cannot be made within 24 hours, the Operator must notify as soon as possible and explain the delay. These notification requirements are in addition to registrant reporting obligations under FIFRA Section 6(a)(2) and 40 CFR Part 159.

Operators are not required to make 24-hour adverse-incident notifications when the incident is clearly unrelated to pesticide toxic effects, when EPA has waived reporting for that incident/category, when the received information is clearly erroneous, or when the incident affects pests similar to labeled target pests (unless it involves threatened or endangered species or critical habitat).
section_summaries.9.0 Permit Conditions Applicable Within: Operators must submit a BRP WM04 application and obtain MassDEP approval before applying chemicals under this permit (with limited exceptions for certain agencies and private, non‑outletting ponds). For alum use, treatments must not cause fish kills, must maintain pond pH between 6.5–8.3 with at least three pH profiles measured through depth across the treatment area, and treatments must be adjusted if outside that range; if post‑treatment pH remains out of range, treated and untreated areas must be sampled for total and dissolved aluminum. Any dead, dying or stressed fish or wildlife and any pH excursions must be reported to the appropriate authorities and documented with required monitoring data and a treatment narrative.

For mosquito and other flying insect pest control in Massachusetts (excluding Indian Country), chemical treatments must be performed by applicators licensed/certified by the MDAR Pesticide Program and comply with M.G.L. c. 252, relevant 333 CMR rules, and State Reclamation and Mosquito Control Board policies. Operators must also follow the Child Protection Act public notification requirements (per M.G.L. c. 132B and 333 CMR 14.00) when applicable.

Antidegradation review requirements depend on the assigned protection tier, receiving-water type, existing baseline water quality, projected impacts, and the nature of the proposed discharge. The guidance applies to regulated discharges that could degrade water quality, including NPDES point sources (CWA §402), discharges placing dredged or fill material (CWA §404), and any federally permitted discharges subject to state certification under CWA §401.

General NPDES permits are not subject to a full Tier 2 antidegradation review, but new and reissued general permits must be evaluated for potential significant degradation. Antidegradation determinations rely on whether permit conditions are met and whether required BMPs effectively limit pollutant loading, with the EPA Region 6 NMIP providing procedural guidance.

The NMWQS Antidegradation Policy and Implementation Plan requires protecting designated uses and existing higher-quality waters when implementing antidegradation between federal and state policies. Permit limits and monitoring must be set to protect state water quality standards and the receiving water’s assimilative capacity, ensuring permits are consistent with designated-use protection.

Describes antidegradation review procedures determined by the water’s protection tier, receiving-water type, baseline water quality, projected impacts, and the proposed discharge’s nature. States that the requirements apply to regulated discharges likely to degrade water quality—including NPDES (Section 402) point sources, discharges placing dredged/fill material (Section 404), and federally permitted discharges subject to state Section 401 certification.

General NPDES permits in New Mexico are not automatically subject to a Tier 2 antidegradation review, but new and reissued general permits must be evaluated for potential significant degradation. Antidegradation decisions focus on whether permit conditions are met and if required BMPs effectively limit pollutant loading; EPA Region 6’s NMIP guidance informs this evaluation.

The section explains that the Antidegradation Policy and Implementation Plan requires NPDES permit limits and monitoring to protect state water quality standards and designated uses, including waters whose existing quality exceeds those uses. Permits must be protective of the receiving water’s assimilative capacity and ensure continued protection of designated uses.

Pesticide applicators under EPA Region 10 water quality permits must be licensed in Washington to apply aquatically labeled pesticides and must comply with Washington law (WAC 16-228, RCW 15.58, and RCW 17.21). This state requirement ensures pesticides are applied legally and appropriately.

Pesticide applications in EPA Region 10 (Washington) must not cause or contribute to violations of Washington Surface Water (ch. 173-201A WAC), Ground Water (ch. 173-200 WAC), Sediment Management (ch. 173-204 WAC) standards, or human health criteria in the National Toxics Rule (40 CFR 131.36). Discharges that fail to meet these standards are prohibited to protect aquatic life, habitats, and human health.

Washington allows short-term exceedances of surface water quality criteria for pesticide treatments if the project meets WAC 173-201A-410; compliance with the Pesticide General Permit satisfies this requirement. All pesticide discharges to water, over water, or at the water’s edge that will enter waters must submit an NOI and obtain coverage under the 2026 Pesticide General Permit, per state antidegradation policy (WAC 173-201A-300) and RCW 90.48.080/90.48.520; Ecology tracks these discharges under its Clean Water Act authority.

Lists the 16 approved aquatic mosquito-control active ingredients under EPA Region 10 (e.g., Bti, Bs, methoprene, malathion, naled, pyrethroids, spinosad, piperonyl butoxide) and points to the Washington Aquatic Mosquito Control General Permit for details. Requires consultation of the WDFW Areas of Restricted Larvicide and Adulticide Use map to avoid harm to endangered, threatened, sensitive, or candidate species; imposes site-specific prohibitions (e.g., malathion and naled banned in vulnerable-species areas, methoprene briquettes banned in marine/estuarine sites) and recommends ULV equipment for adulticide applications.

Lists approved pesticides and product types for freshwater aquatic weed and algae management (e.g., 2,4‑D, glyphosate, fluridone, diquat, endothall, peroxyacetic/peracetic acid, sodium carbonate peroxyhydrate, nutrient inactivation products, marker dyes and water clarification products) and directs users to WSDA for adjuvant approval; water-clarification products are restricted to waterbodies with no discharge to other state surface waters during and for two weeks after treatment. Sets maximum percentages of littoral zones that may be treated with herbicides by waterbody size (e.g., ≤15 acres 75%; >500 acres 30%) with specified exceptions, and allows targeted algaecide use for filamentous algae and whole/partial treatments for cyanobacteria but requires pre/post dissolved-oxygen monitoring and specified alternatives/limits when monitoring or DO risk is infeasible.

Authorizes herbicide applications for shoreline and emergent noxious weeds in Washington (EPA Region 10) only where pesticides are not directly discharged to water and only for state-listed noxious weeds or WSDA-quarantined species. Provides a list of approved active ingredients (e.g., aminopyralid, glyphosate, triclopyr TEA, imazapyr, penoxsulam, etc.), requires WSDA approval for adjuvants, allows marker dyes, and cites RCW/WAC authorities and AKART-based justification.

Treatments for non‑native Zostera japonica are restricted to commercial clam beds in Willapa Bay with a single annual imazamox application allowed April 15–June 30, a required 10‑meter internal parcel buffer (unless waived by adjacent bed owners), prohibition on treating geoduck beds or applying imazamox into drainage containing Z. marina leaving the site, and a ban on adjuvants. Restrictions are justified as AKART-based water quality protections and are supported by multiple Washington statutes and WAC citations.

Specifies Washington State conditions for irrigation-system aquatic weed control, including an approved list of pesticides and a contact for which adjuvants are allowed. Requires that treated water not exceed specified maximum instantaneous concentration limits for listed actives at the point of compliance and cites state permit, AKART, and relevant RCW/WAC authorities.

Defines conditions for aquatic invasive species control in WA (EPA Region 10) including which non-native marine and freshwater species may be targeted (per WAC, Washington Invasive Species Council, Lacey Act, state quarantine lists, or agency determination). Lists approved treatment agents for marine/freshwater (salts, chlorine compounds, acetic acid, lime/CO2) and freshwater-only options (endothall, sodium carbonate peroxyhydrate, methoprene, chelated copper, Pseudomonas fluorescens CL 145A), and requires proponents to consult WDFW AIS staff prior to treatment.

Rotenone products registered in Washington State are approved for fish management, with potassium permanganate (KMnO4) the only authorized chemical to deactivate treated waters. Project proponents must consult the WDFW Fish Program and follow the latest Rotenone SOP Manual, and comply with water-rights/replacement-water and AKART/state water quality requirements (see section 8 and cited RCW/WACs).

Lists pesticides approved for invasive insect control in Washington (e.g., Bacillus thuringiensis var. kurstaki, pheromones, chlorantraniliprole, cyfluthrin, imidacloprid, Japanese beetle nematode) and requires WSDA confirmation for adjuvants. Requires a minimum 3-day interval before re-treating the same area and mandates project proponents notify WDFW 60 days before treatment regarding state-listed threatened/endangered/candidate species; includes relevant links and statutory citations.

Washington State imposes specific conditions on forest canopy pest control to protect aquatic life, sensitive/threatened species, and water quality; project proponents must follow Title 76 RCW. Ecology cites restrictions on allowed active ingredients and on when/how pesticides may be applied as technology-based AKART measures necessary to meet state water quality standards.

Project proponents must publish a newspaper notice in the treatment area before the first seasonal application listing the treatment schedule, water body name, pesticides/chemicals, any water-use restrictions, contact information for the proponent and agency staff, and Ecology’s 24-hour emergency number. Notices must explain the project and state that treated areas will be posted no more than 48 hours before treatment to protect public health and reduce exposure.

Project proponents must use Ecology shoreline posting templates (links provided) and post signs at reasonable public access points to notify chemical aquatic treatments, extending up to 400 feet beyond treatment boundaries where feasible. Signs must be posted no more than 48 hours before treatment, in commonly spoken local languages, and removed after water-use restrictions end; cited authorities include RCW 90.48.010 and WAC 173-226-130.

For EPA Region 10 (Ecology), project proponents must identify and notify potable, irrigation, and livestock water users with valid water rights/claims (via Ecology’s water-rights resources) before chemical treatments—initial notification annually and sooner if treatments recur. If requested, proponents must provide at least two weeks’ advance notice and, at their expense, supply replacement/alternative water that allows customary use until testing shows concentrations at or below the product label’s specified limit; proponents and affected users must agree on how replacement water will be provided.

Project proponents must consult and comply with WDFW waterbody-specific timing windows (map and contact provided) before conducting aquatic treatments, and follow WDFW consultation and treatment limits where required. Exceptions include emergent/shoreline plants, roadside/ditch/flood-control vegetation, and nonnative fish (optional compliance); modified timing windows can be requested via the regional WDFW biologist, and certain pesticides (e.g., 2,4‑D, carfentrazone‑ethyl, chelated copper, chlorine, diquat, endothall, flumioxazin, potassium permanganate, rotenone) and an irrigation-canal endothall exception are noted, with Ecology required to follow statutory WDFW mandates.

Before any herbicide or algaecide treatment, project proponents must consult the WA DNR Natural Heritage Program (map and contact provided) to determine if sensitive/threatened/endangered plants are present; if so, they must survey, consult DNR staff, and implement mitigations prior to pesticide application. The requirement is tied to WDFW protection mandates and RCW 79.70 citations.

Describes the 30-day right to appeal the Order to the Pollution Control Hearings Board (PCHB) under RCW 43.21B and WAC 371-08, requiring filing a notice of appeal and a copy of the Order (actual receipt by PCHB during business hours) and serving the Department of Ecology by mail, in person, or email. Provides PCHB filing contact (https://eluho.wa.gov/, (360) 664-9160) and the Department of Ecology appeals mailing address and email.

Lists the contact for questions about the Order under EPA Region 10 notification requirements: Danielle Edelman at the Washington Department of Ecology, with full mailing address (P.O. Box 47600, Olympia, WA 98503-7600), phone (360-407-7118), and email (danielle.edelman@ecy.wa.gov).

Provides links to Washington State resources relevant to EPA Region 10 notification requirements, including the Pollution Control Hearings Board website and governing statutes on practice and procedure. References specific RCW and WAC chapters covering administrative procedure, water pollution control, sediment management, and water quality standards for both ground and surface waters.

This section lists tribal-specific permit and notification requirements for Indian Country in Washington under EPA Region 10. Most tribes (e.g., Chehalis, Colville, Kalispel, Puyallup, Quinault, Spokane, Squaxin Island, Swinomish, Tulalip) have no additional requirements, while the Lummi Nation requires land-use permits, compliance with Lummi water quality standards, immediate notification of unauthorized pesticide releases, and submission of the NOI to Lummi authorities. The Makah Tribe requires advance notice (at least 7 business days, preferably 30), and Jamestown S'Klallam requires cessation and notification plus development of an adaptive plan if pesticide applications impact tribal resources.

Lists EPA Region 1 permit code prefixes and the specific areas where EPA is the permitting authority: Indian Country within Connecticut (CTG87####E), Massachusetts (MAG87####), Rhode Island (RIG87####E), and all unaddressed Indian Country (01G87####E); New Hampshire (NHG87####) and federal facilities in Vermont (VTG87####E); and lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction (01G87####).

Lists permit-condition identifiers and their geographic coverage in EPA Region 2 where EPA is the permitting authority, including Indian Country within New York (NYG87####E), Puerto Rico (PRG87####), other Indian Country not covered by state programs (02G87####E), and lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction (02G87####). This helps locate which permit codes apply to specific territories and federal lands.

Lists the specific area codes and descriptions for locations in EPA Region 3 where EPA is the permitting authority: DCG87#### (The District of Columbia), DEG87####E (federal facilities within Delaware), VAG87####E (Indian Country within Virginia), 03G87####E (all other Indian Country not covered by an EPA‑approved permitting program), and 03G87#### (lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction).

Lists permit-condition location codes used when EPA (not a state) is the permitting authority in Region 4 (AL, FL, GA, KY, MS, NC, SC, TN), including specific Indian Country codes (ALG87####E, FLG87####E, MSG87####E, NCG87####E) and general codes for all other Indian Country not covered by an EPA‑approved program (04G87####E) and for lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction (04G87####).

Defines EPA permitting-authority codes for Indian Country in Region 5: ILG87####E (Illinois), ING87####E (Indiana), MIG87####E (Michigan), MNG87####E (Minnesota, excluding Fond du Lac and Leech Lake), and WIG87####E (Wisconsin, excluding Lac du Flambeau, Bad River, and Sokaogon). Also includes 05G87####E for all other Indian Country not covered by an EPA-approved program and 05G87#### for lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction.

Lists EPA permitting-authority area codes for Region 6: Indian Country within Louisiana (LAG87####E), Oklahoma (OKG87####E), and Texas (TXG87####E); New Mexico including Indian Country except Navajo Reservation and Ute Mountain Reservation (NMG87####); all other Indian Country not covered by an approved program (06G87####E); and lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction (06G87####).

Lists locations in EPA Region 7 where EPA is the permitting authority: Indian Country within Iowa (IAG87####E), Kansas (KSG87####E), and Nebraska except Pine Ridge Reservation (NEG87####E); other Indian Country not covered by an EPA‑approved state program (07G87####E); and lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction (07G87####). Users will search for permit jurisdiction and location codes for Region 7.

Enumerates EPA permitting-authority areas using location codes for Indian Country and federal facilities across several states (CO, MT, ND, SD, UT, WY), identifies specific reservation inclusions/exclusions (e.g., portion of Ute Mountain Reservation, Pine Ridge Reservation in NE handled by Region 7, Goshute/Navajo handled by Region 9), and includes catch-all codes for other Indian Country and lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction.

Table maps EPA Region 9 permit codes to the specific areas where EPA is the permitting authority, including states, U.S. territories, Pacific islands, and named Indian Country reservations. It also notes listed tribal exclusions and cross-references to other EPA regions for certain reservations.

Specifies the areas in EPA Region 10 where EPA is the permitting authority: Indian Country in Alaska (AKG87####E), Idaho (IDG87####E) except Duck Valley Reservation, and Oregon (ORG87####E) except Fort McDermitt Reservation; federal facilities and Indian Country in Washington lacking an EPA‑approved program (WAG87####E); plus catch‑all codes for other Indian Country not covered by approved programs (10G87####E) and lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction (10G87####).

Explains that a paper Notice of Intent (NOI) may be used only if an EPA Regional Office has granted a waiver from mandatory electronic reporting, and requires indicating which waiver (broadband underserved area or limited computer access), the name of the EPA staff who approved it, and the approval date. If no waiver is obtained, the NOI must be filed electronically via EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool (NetT).

Indicate whether this is the first request for coverage under the 2026 PGP (Original NOI) or a change to an existing NOI. If changing information, provide the NPDES permit tracking number and complete Section B (Operator Name and Mailing Address) plus any NOI fields being modified.

Collects operator identification and contact details for the NOI, including operator name, selected operator type (with NAICS code if available), whether the operator is a "large entity" (which triggers a required Pesticide Discharge Management Plan and Annual Report), the single state where pest management occurs, and full mailing/contact information (address, phone, fax, contact name, email).

Section C requests detailed information for each pest management area seeking PGP coverage: name and geospatial map, whether activities occur on Indian Country or federal land (including exclusive federal jurisdiction), applicator mailing/contact details, selected pesticide use patterns, specification of receiving waters (or exclusions), and whether discharges affect Tier or impaired waters—requiring names, rationale, and supporting attachments as applicable.

Section D requires completing an Endangered Species Protection form for each pest management area, selecting one of six ESA eligibility criteria (A–G), and submitting supporting documentation including a Project Action Area map and list of FWS/NMFS Listed Resources of Concern generated with EPA’s geospatial mapping tool within 90 days of NOI submittal. If listed resources are present or a pest emergency applies, the NOI must include evidence of authorized take or a description of anticipated effects, feasible avoidance/mitigation measures, and notification/coordination emails to FWS, NMFS, and EPA.

Lists selectable attachments for the NOI form, including responses/documentation for C.3 (Land of Exclusive Federal Jurisdiction), C.7b (Tier 3 waters), C.8b (impaired waters), Endangered Species Protection criteria (A, C, D, E, F, G) with the ESA Criterion Selection Worksheet (Appendix I), the Pesticide Discharge Management Plan, and space for other supporting documents.

Requires the responsible official to certify under penalty of law that the NOI and attachments were prepared under their supervision and are true, accurate, and complete, and to provide printed name, title, email, signature, and date. If someone other than the certifier prepared the NOI, a separate NOI Preparer subsection collects the preparer’s name, organization, phone (and extension), date, and email.

This subsection of Appendix E provides the Permit Information portion of a paper Notice of Termination form, asking for the NPDES Permit Tracking Number and a single reason for termination (ceased discharges, obtained individual/alternative permit, or transfer to a new operator). If selecting transfer, the form requires the transfer date and full new operator contact details (name, address, phone, and email).

Specifies the operator information required on the paper Notice of Termination (electronic submission waiver) form: operator name, full mailing address (street, city, state, ZIP+4), telephone number (with extension), contact name, and contact email.

The signer certifies they meet at least one stated reason for terminating permit coverage, acknowledges that submission ends authorization to discharge pesticides to U.S. waters, and attests the form and attachments were prepared under their supervision and are true, accurate, and complete to the best of their knowledge. The certification warns of significant penalties for false information and clarifies that submitting the Notice of Termination does not relieve the operator of liability for Clean Water Act violations; signature block includes printed name, title, email, signature, and date.

This subsection of Appendix E (Approval to Use Paper NOT / Electronic Submission Waiver) captures the NOT Preparer information to be completed when the person who prepared the Notice of Termination is different from the certifier. It requests preparer name, organization, phone (with extension), date, and email for contact and verification purposes.

This section is the General Information form of the Pesticide Discharge Evaluation Worksheet (Appendix F) for the PGP, collecting operator and NPDES identifiers and worksheet preparer. It documents pest management area number and name, selectable pesticide use patterns (mosquito/flying insects, weeds/algae, animal, forest canopy), and—for each treatment area—location/description, size (acres or linear feet), and any waters of the United States receiving discharges.

The Pest Evaluation section of the Pesticide Discharge Evaluation Worksheet asks permittees to identify target pest(s) and explain why control is needed, and to describe pest management measures implemented before the first pesticide application. It supports documentation required under the PGP Appendix F to justify pesticide use and prior mitigation steps.

Worksheet collects pesticide applicator contact details, start/end application dates, each product name with EPA registration number and quantity applied, and the application method; it also documents whether visual monitoring occurred (with date/time/location) and any observed adverse effects and descriptions.

This section contains the certification statement for the Pesticide Discharge Evaluation Worksheet requiring a responsible official’s printed name, title, email, signature, and date. The signer attests under penalty of law that the submission was prepared under their direction/supervision, is true, accurate, and complete, and acknowledges criminal/financial penalties for knowingly false information.

Form section for identifying the worksheet preparer (when different from the certifier), capturing preparer name, organization, phone number and extension, email, and date. Includes an image/placeholder area (likely for an email/signature field).
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > **A: This form collects general identification and contact information for the annual pesticide activities report, including the NPDES permit tracking number, operator name, and full operator mailing address. It also requests phone/fax numbers and primary contact details (name, title, and email) for the specified calendar year.

Form section asks whether any adverse incidents or corrective actions occurred and, if so, requires per–pest-management-area details: incident date, EPA notification date/time and contact/instructions, date of the 30‑day written adverse incident report, and a description/rationale of corrective actions (including spill responses). Copy the section for additional pest management areas as needed.

Template for reporting each pest management area: whether any discharges occurred, pesticide use pattern (mosquito, weed/algae, animal, forest), and detailed treatment-area info including geospatial map, size, adjacent waters, target pests, and any FWS/NMFS resource exposures and dates. Requires documentation of visual monitoring during and after application, applicator contact details, whether the activity was covered by the PDMP, and the total amounts applied by product (with EPA reg. no.) and by application method (aerial, land-based, aquatic, direct, chemigation, etc.).

Official certification where a responsible official attests under penalty of law that the report and attachments were prepared under their supervision, that the information is true, accurate, and complete to the best of their knowledge, and that they are unaware of any false information. Includes required fields for Printed Name, Title, E‑Mail, Signature/Responsible Official, and Date, and warns of possible fines or imprisonment for knowing violations.

Provides the Annual Report Preparer fields (name, organization, phone, date, email) to be completed when someone other than the certifier prepares a paper annual report under an electronic submission waiver. Lists EPA mailing and overnight/express addresses for paper filing, requires original paper reports with an ink signature (no copies/faxes), reminds operators to use NetT unless granted a waiver, and notes the annual report due date (February 15) and NPDES eReporting help contact information.

Instructions for completing EPA Form 6100-25, including the requirement to indicate and document any EPA Regional Office waiver to use the paper annual report instead of electronic submission. Explains what to provide in Sections A–C (permit/tracking number, decision-maker/contact info, adverse incidents and corrective actions, detailed pest management area descriptions and monitoring records) and the mandatory authorized-official signature/certification in Section D; includes the Paperwork Reduction Act notice estimating an 8-hour reporting burden.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > UNI: Defines when an adverse pesticide incident is reportable and lists exceptions (not pesticide-related toxic effects/exposure, EPA-waived, clearly erroneous information, or incidents affecting pests similar to labeled target pests except as noted for threatened/endangered species). If reportable, the Operator must submit the completed 30-day report to the appropriate EPA Regional office and state pesticide agency; if not reportable, reporting is not required though retaining a completed form and rationale is recommended.

Section B requires the 24-hour adverse incident notification details be included in the 30-day written report: caller and operator contact information (including NOI/NPDES tracking number), an alternate contact if applicable, a concise narrative of how and when the operator became aware of the incident, the incident location, description of pesticides used (with EPA registration numbers), and steps taken or planned to remediate and any other notified/authorized operators.

Form fields to record when the operator contacted EPA about an adverse incident (date and time), the name and title of the EPA person contacted, and any instructions EPA provided. Part of the 30‑day written adverse incident report template for the Pesticide General Permit (PGP).

Lists required content for the 30‑day adverse incident report: incident location and water appearance; circumstances and species affected with estimated counts; magnitude/area of impact; detailed pesticide application information (rate, intended use site, method, product name, EPA Reg. No., with space for multiple entries); habitat and ambient water data; laboratory tests (with timing and follow‑up results) and actions taken to prevent recurrence. Attach additional information as needed.

Responsible official must certify under penalty of law that the report and attachments were prepared under their supervision, are true, accurate, and complete to the best of their knowledge, and acknowledge penalties (fines/imprisonment) for false submissions. The form requires the printed name, title, e-mail, signature of the responsible official, and the date.

This section collects contact information for the person who prepared the 30-day Adverse Incident Report when that preparer is someone other than the certifier. It requests preparer name, organization, phone number (with extension), date, and email for follow-up.

Provides step-by-step instructions and required content for completing the PGP 30-day Adverse Incident Written Report, including reportability determination, information copied from the 24‑hour (and threatened/endangered species) notifications (caller/operator info, incident location, detailed incident description, affected non‑target organisms, EPA registration numbers, and cleanup actions), EPA contact/date/time, pesticide application details, lab test reporting/timelines, planned prevention measures, strict signer/certification rules (who may sign and penalties for false statements), and the Paperwork Reduction Act burden estimate (~4 hours).
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > App: Defines key terms (FWS/NMFS Listed Resources of Concern, Project Action Area, Pest Management Area) and explains that Step 1 of the worksheet is required to determine ESA eligibility by identifying species/critical habitat potentially exposed by pesticide discharges. Directs Decision-makers to use EPA’s geospatial mapping tool (and approved Service data like IPaC), notes NMFS jurisdiction over marine/estuarine species, and warns that ESA Section 9 prohibits unlawful ‘take’ with potential penalties.

Use EPA’s geospatial mapping tool to determine whether FWS and/or NMFS Listed Resources of Concern occur in the Project Action Area; the tool provides a map and species/critical habitat list (tool output available within 90 days). If no listed resources are present, include the map and list with the NOI or retain them if no NOI is required; if resources are present, proceed to the next worksheet step (or Step 6 for a Declared Pest Emergency). Paper-NOI waivers must also include the map, list, and worksheet.
section_summaries.Appendices > 1.1 Eligibility > 1.1.1 Act: This permit applies to operators discharging biological pesticides or chemical pesticides that leave a residue to waters of the United States. Covered pesticide use patterns include mosquito and other flying insect control; weed and algae control (including water’s edge and ditches/canals); animal pest control (e.g., fish, lampreys, insects, mollusks, pathogens); and forest canopy pest control where some pesticide will unavoidably deposit to water.
section_summaries.Appendices > 1.2 Authorization to Discha: Certain eligible discharges are automatically authorized under the permit beginning October 31, 2026—notably those from pesticide research and development (see Appendix A) and other discharges that do not require an NOI. For all other eligible discharges, the Decision-maker must submit a timely, complete, and accurate NOI consistent with Parts 1.2.2 and 1.2.3; see Part 1.1.2.4 and Table 1-1 for details on NOI requirements.

Decision-makers listed in Table 1-1 (per PGP use patterns and Appendix A definitions) must submit an NOI when their pesticide application discharges meet the annual treatment area threshold. The NOI (see Appendix D) must identify the pest management area and any Tier 3 waters, and generally must be filed via EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool (NeT); EPA will post NOIs and late submissions are accepted but not retroactive. Coverage under the permit extends for its duration to the Decision-maker and their employees/contractors for activities listed on a timely, accurate, and complete NOI; applicators who are not Decision-makers do not need to submit an NOI.

Operators with eligible discharges are generally automatically authorized under the permit unless listed in Tables 1-1 through 1-3; Decision-makers with discharges identified in those tables must submit an NOI by the deadlines in Table 1-2 to obtain authorization. EPA may delay authorization, require additional controls, or deny permit coverage based on NOI review and ESA eligibility; Table 1-2 specifies NOI submission deadlines and discharge authorization dates (typically no earlier than 30 days after EPA posts a complete NOI), with immediate coverage allowed for Declared Pest Emergency Situations subject to notification and coordination with FWS/NMFS.

If the permit expires without reissuance, it is administratively continued under 40 CFR 122.6 and remains in effect for previously authorized dischargers until the earliest of: coverage under a reissued/replacement permit (or timely NOI), a processed Notice of Termination, issuance/denial of an individual NPDES permit for the discharge, EPA’s formal decision not to reissue (with a transition period), or EPA notice that the discharge is no longer covered.

Decision-makers required to file an NOI must submit a complete Notice of Termination (NOT) via EPA’s NeT within 30 days after specified triggers (new Decision-maker, cessation of discharges, or obtaining alternate NPDES coverage). Authorization ends at 11:59 p.m. on the day the NOT is processed and posted on EPA’s pesticide-permitting website; Decision-makers remain responsible until termination and must file any required annual report for the period up to termination (due by Feb 15). Operators not required to submit an NOI have permit coverage end when pesticide discharges cease or no longer occur.
section_summaries.Appendices > 1.3 Alternative Permits > 1: Under 40 CFR 122.64 and 124.5, EPA can require Operators to apply for an NPDES individual permit (or an alternative general permit) and will provide written notice explaining the decision and application details. The notice sets a deadline to submit an application, may allow extensions for good cause, and states that coverage under the general permit ends when the individual permit takes effect; failure to apply by the deadline terminates general-permit applicability and may lead to enforcement for unpermitted discharges or permit violations.

Operators who do not want coverage under this general permit can apply for an individual NPDES permit by submitting an application and reasons under 40 CFR 122.26(c)(1)(ii) to the applicable EPA Regional Office listed in Part 8; the Agency may issue an individual permit or authorize coverage under an alternative general permit. If an individual NPDES permit is issued or authorization under an alternative general permit is granted for pesticide-related discharges, coverage under this permit terminates on the effective date of that authorization.
