section_summaries.2.0 Technology-Based Effluent Limitation: Decision-makers required to submit an NOI must, before the first annual pesticide application, establish action thresholds, identify target pests and breeding sites, and analyze surveillance data for each pest management area; they must select and implement pest management measures that minimize discharges (evaluating options from no action to pesticides). If pesticides are used, conduct representative larval/adult surveillance before each application, apply only when thresholds are met, and prefer larvicides where feasible, using adulticides only when larvicides are not practicable.

Applies to discharges from pesticides used to control weeds, algae, and pathogens and requires Decision-makers (who must submit an NOI) to annually and before the first application identify affected areas, target pests, contributing causes, and set pest- and site-specific action thresholds. Decision-makers must select and implement Pest Management Measures that minimize discharges by evaluating options (no action, prevention, mechanical/physical, cultural, biological, pesticides) for water quality, non‑target impacts, feasibility, and cost. If a pesticide that will discharge to waters is used, representative pre-application surveillance is required.

Applies to discharges from pesticide use for animal pest control and requires Decision-makers who must submit an NOI to (a) annually identify pest management areas, target pests, contributing factors, and site-specific action thresholds; (b) select and implement Pest Management Measures that minimize discharges—evaluating options such as no action, prevention, mechanical, cultural, biological, and pesticides; and (c) if pesticides will discharge, conduct pre-application surveillance in representative areas to determine when action thresholds are met.

Applies to pesticide applications for forest canopy pest control and requires Decision-makers (who must file an NOI) to annually and before the first seasonal application: establish pest- and site-specific action thresholds, identify target pests and their distribution, and use available data if recent local data are lacking. Decision-makers must select and implement Pest Management Measures (no action, prevention, mechanical, cultural, biological, or chemical) that minimize discharges to waters, considering water quality, non-target impacts, feasibility, and cost; if pesticides will discharge to waters, conduct pre-application surveillance in representative areas to determine when thresholds are met.
section_summaries.5.0 Pesticide Discharge Management Plan: Decision-makers must list all PDMP team members by name and contact information and specify each person’s responsibilities, including who manages pests in the pest management area, who develops and revises the PDMP, and who develops, revises, and implements corrective actions and other effluent limitation requirements.

Decision-makers must document the pest problem (target pests, sources, and supporting data), define action threshold(s) with the data and methods used to determine when thresholds are met, include a general location map showing plan boundaries and nearby waters of the U.S., and note any Tier 3 waters or waters impaired by substances that are active ingredients or degradates relevant to the plan.

Decision-makers must document an evaluation of pest management options (including no action, prevention, mechanical/physical, cultural, biological control, and pesticides) and any combinations used to control target pests. The evaluation must consider impacts to water quality and non-target organisms, feasibility, cost-effectiveness, and relevant prior Pest Management Measures.

PDMPs must document procedures for spill response (stop, contain, clean up), required training, and availability of spill-response equipment, plus notification steps to facility, emergency, and regulatory agencies. They must also include adverse-incident response and notification procedures with accessible contact information, and visual monitoring plans specifying locations, schedule, responsible person, and documentation requirements (date, time, location).

Requires decision-makers to keep in the PDMP all documentation supporting their eligibility determinations under other federal laws, specifically the Endangered and Threatened Species and Critical Habitat protections referenced in Part 1.1.2.4.

Authorized decision-makers must sign, date, and certify the Pesticide Discharge Management Plan (PDMP) to meet the legal requirements of 40 CFR 122.41(k), establishing formal responsibility for the plan’s contents.
section_summaries.6.0 Corrective Action > 6.4 Adverse Inci: Within 30 days of a reportable adverse incident (except as noted in 6.4.4), Operators must submit a written report to the appropriate EPA Regional office, the state pesticide lead (and Tribal lead if applicable). The report must include initial report details, EPA contact and instructions, incident location and water appearance, species affected and estimated counts, scope/area affected, pesticide product/registration, application rate/method/use site, habitat and ambient data, any lab tests (with results provided within 5 days when available), planned corrective actions, and a signature with certification per 40 CFR 122.41(k).

Operators must immediately telephone NMFS (for anadromous/marine species) or FWS (for terrestrial/freshwater species) using the contacts on EPA’s pesticide permitting page if a pesticide discharge may have caused an adverse incident to federally-listed species or critical habitat. The report must include caller contact, operator name/address, affected species, how/when discovered, location, incident details (including non-target organisms and pesticide product with EPA reg. number) and steps taken; operators should leave organisms alone, document location/extent and photos, and may be instructed by the Services to collect specimens or other evidence.

If multiple Operators are authorized for a discharge that causes an adverse incident, notification and reporting by any one Operator satisfies the reporting obligation for all Operators, provided the written report required by Part 6.4.2 is shared with the other authorized Operators within 30 days of the incident.
section_summaries.6.0 Corrective Action > 6.5 Reportable S: Operators must immediately notify the National Response Center (800-424-8802; 202-267-2675 in D.C. area) when a spill, leak, or unpermitted discharge of oil or hazardous substances equals or exceeds the reportable quantity under 40 CFR Parts 110, 117, or 302 within any 24-hour period; contact information must be readily accessible at potential release locations. State or local agencies may also require separate reporting to emergency response, public health, or drinking water authorities.

If a spill, leak, or unpermitted discharge triggers 6.5.1 but does not cause an adverse incident, the Operator must document and retain within 30 days: the information required by 6.5.1, a corrective-action summary with start/completion dates (or expected dates), and measures to prevent recurrence including whether PDMP modifications are needed. Incidents that result in adverse effects must be reported per 6.4.1 and 6.4.2.
section_summaries.8.0 EPA Contact Information and Mailing: Provides the United States Postal Service mailing address for EPA Headquarters — Office of Water, Water Permits Division (ATTN: NPDES Pesticides), Mail Code 4203M, 1200 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington, DC 20460.

Overnight/express delivery address for EPA Headquarters submissions to the Office of Water, Water Permits Division (ATTN: NPDES Pesticides), Room 7420: 1201 Constitution Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20004.

Contact information for EPA Region 1 (serving Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, Vermont, and Maine), listing the Water Division mailing address: 5 Post Office Square, Suite 100, Boston, MA 02109-3912. Useful for users searching for regional EPA water program contacts or mailing addresses.

Provides mailing addresses for EPA Region 2, covering New Jersey, New York, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands: Caribbean Environmental Protection Division (Multimedia Permits and Compliance Branch) in Guaynabo, PR (City View Plaza II, 48 Carr 165, Suite 7000, Guaynabo, PR 00968-8073), and the Region 2 Water Division office in New York, NY (290 Broadway, 24th Floor, New York, NY 10007-1866).

Provides the EPA Region 3 Clean Water Branch (Water Division 3WD41) mailing address in Philadelphia (Four Penn Center, 1600 John F. Kennedy Boulevard, Philadelphia, PA 19103) and indicates this regional office serves Delaware, the District of Columbia, Maryland, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and West Virginia.

Mailing address for U.S. EPA Region 4 Water Protection Division located at Atlanta Federal Center, 61 Forsyth Street SW, Atlanta, GA 30303. Covers Region 4 states: Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Tennessee.

Lists EPA Region 5 contact for the Water Division, Permits Branch (WP-16J) including the mailing address: 77 W. Jackson Boulevard, Chicago, IL 60604; applies to Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, Ohio, and Wisconsin.

Contact/mailing information for EPA Region 6 (covers Arkansas, Louisiana, Oklahoma, Texas, and New Mexico) Permitting and Water Quality Branch (R6 WD-P) located at 1201 Elm Street, Suite 500, Dallas, TX 75270. Notes that Navajo lands are handled by Region 9 and the Ute Mountain Reservation by Region 8.

Contact information for EPA Region 7 (serving Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, and Nebraska), specifically the Permits and Wetlands (PAW) Branch of the Water Division, located at 11201 Renner Blvd., Lenexa, KS 66219.

Lists EPA Region 8 coverage and provides the Region 8 mailing address and office code. Office: 8WD-CWW, 1595 Wynkoop Street, Denver, CO 80202-1129; covers Colorado, Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota, Wyoming, Utah (with Goshute and Navajo reservations handled by Region 9), plus the Ute Mountain Reservation (NM) and Pine Ridge Reservation (NE).

Provides the mailing/contact address for U.S. EPA Region 9 Water Division (WTR-2-3) at 75 Hawthorne Street, San Francisco, CA 94105, and lists the jurisdictions covered: Arizona, California, Hawaii, Nevada, Guam, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, plus specific tribal lands (Goshute Reservation in UT and NV; Navajo Reservation in UT, NM, and AZ; Duck Valley Reservation in ID; and Fort McDermitt Reservation in OR).

Lists the mailing/contact address for EPA Region 10’s Water Division (19-C04), which serves Alaska, Idaho, Oregon (except Fort McDermitt Reservation), and Washington: United States EPA Region 10, Water Division 19-C04, 1200 6th Avenue, Suite 155, Seattle, WA 98101.
section_summaries.9.0 Permit Conditions Applicable Within: Operators in Massachusetts must comply with MassDEP water quality standards—discharges to Outstanding Resource Waters require authorization, pesticides must not be applied to vernal pools, and operators must control discharges to meet toxic pollutant standards. The section also provides PFAS-related guidance (avoid fluorinated HDPE containers and certain formulations), requires BRP WM04 approval and specific monitoring/reporting (including alum pH limits and fish/wildlife mortality) for most weed/algae treatments, and mandates MDAR certification and adherence to state pesticide, wetlands, endangered species, and spill reporting rules for mosquito and other pest controls.
Section 9.1.4 (State of New Hampshire) states there are no additional state-specific permit conditions—only the standard federal permit requirements apply.

This subsection notes that the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico has no additional state- or territory-specific permit conditions beyond the general permit terms. Users searching for Puerto Rico-specific permit requirements will find none in this section.

Permittees discharging in the District of Columbia must comply with the DC Water Pollution Control Act, DC Water Quality Standards (21 DCMR Chapter 11) and monitoring rules (21 DCMR Chapter 19), and applicable pesticide laws (e.g., Pesticide Education and Control Amendment Act). Reporting and notification requirements (including 40 CFR §122.41) must be made available to the Chief, Illicit Discharge and NPDES Branch, Dept. of Energy and Environment (1200 First Street NE, 5th Floor, Washington, DC 20002; (202) 805-1355). For federal facilities in Delaware, no additional requirements are listed.

Pesticide applications within the Lac du Flambeau Band, Bad River Band, and Sokaogon Chippewa Community in Wisconsin are not eligible for coverage under this permit; interested parties must contact EPA Region 5 to apply for an individual permit.
Section 9.6.1 states that for Indian Country within the State of Louisiana (EPA Region 6) there are no additional permit conditions beyond those already specified.

The Draft PGP requires operators to comply with applicable state pesticide laws. The New Mexico Pesticide Control Act (NMSA 1978 §§76-4-1 to -39) gives the New Mexico Department of Agriculture authority over pesticides and applicators and establishes definitions, licensing/certification, fee limits, and grounds for license denial/suspension/revocation. Related NMAC regulations (e.g., 21.17.50, 20.17.51, 20.17.53, 21.17.56) set criteria for pesticide use in NM, including recordkeeping, equipment inspection, storage/disposal, continuing education, and controls on restricted-use pesticides.

Part 1.1.2.2 of the Draft PGP allows certain pesticide discharges to Tier 3 Outstanding National Resource Waters (ONRWs) when they are intended to restore or maintain water quality or protect public health or the environment, provided they do not degrade water quality or only cause short-term or temporary degradation. This background explains the limited exception for pesticide applications affecting ONRWs and the conditions under which such discharges may be permitted.

Cites New Mexico regulations governing discharges affecting Outstanding National Resource Waters (ONRWs): filing Notices of Intent with state bureaus, the definition of an oversight agency, and an antidegradation policy that generally prohibits degradation of ONRWs except for narrowly defined temporary public health/safety actions subject to a minimum 30‑day public review, strict duration/mitigation limits (e.g., six months), required public notice and comment responses, and post‑treatment assessment monitoring; NPDES applicants must notify local entities and follow related WQMP/CPP guidance.

General NPDES permits cover discharges such as Phase II MS4 stormwater, industrial stormwater (MSGP), construction stormwater, pesticide applications, and CAFOs; authorization requires compliance with permit terms and failure to meet conditions or antidegradation requirements can trigger the need for an individual permit. General permits are not subject to a full Tier 2 antidegradation review, but new or reissued general permits must be evaluated for potential significant degradation based on compliance with permit conditions and the effectiveness of required BMPs, following procedural guidance such as EPA Region 6’s NMIP.

Cites New Mexico NMAC requirements for filing a notice of intent to discharge (who must file and required details such as name, address, discharge location, contaminant concentrations and quantities). Summarizes the state antidegradation policy allowing limited, controlled degradation for restoration/maintenance activities if degradation is time‑limited, minimized (via BMPs and permit conditions), and does not lower water quality below levels needed to protect existing uses; antidegradation review applies to regulated discharges including NPDES point sources, Section 404 dredge/fill activities, and federally permitted discharges subject to Section 401 certification. Notes the general criterion that surface waters must be free of toxic pollutants at levels harmful to aquatic life, wildlife, livestock, or humans.

General NPDES permits authorize many discharges (e.g., Phase II MS4, industrial and construction stormwater, pesticides, CAFOs) but require compliance with permit terms and BMPs—noncompliant discharges must seek individual permits. New or reissued general permits in New Mexico are evaluated for potential significant degradation (not automatically Tier 2), using EPA Region 6 NMIP guidance to ensure permit limits and monitoring protect water quality, designated uses, and the receiving water’s assimilative capacity.

20.6.4.13 NMAC requires surface waters be free of toxic pollutants that harm aquatic life or human/animal health, except as allowed under 20.6.4.16. 20.6.4.16 sets additional notification, monitoring and approval requirements for planned piscicide use under NPDES permits and specifies required contents of a Notice of Intent (applicant and piscicide ID, FIFRA/NMPCA registration, target and non‑target species including threatened/endangered species, environmental consequences and mitigation, waters to be treated, pre‑treatment survey, alternatives analysis, and documentation of public notice and comments to specified local entities).

Explains the Background for Condition #5 (Spill and Adverse Incident Notification and Removal Requirements), summarizing Draft PGP Part 5.1.4 which requires decision-makers to establish procedures for notifying and reporting spills and adverse incidents. Covers notification triggers, reporting timelines, responsible parties, and obligations for removal/response under permit conditions applicable in specific states, territories, and Indian Country.

Facilities must orally notify the chief of the Ground Water Quality Bureau (or delegated agency) within 24 hours of any discharge likely to harm health, the environment, or property, providing specific details (responsible persons, facility location, date/time, source/cause, chemical description, estimated volume, and mitigation actions). A written verification with any additions/corrections is required within one week; when unsure which agency to contact, notify the bureau. The rule does not duplicate OCC/OCD reporting requirements, limits criminal use of notification information except for perjury/false statements, encourages public reporting, and allows the secretary to require corrective actions.

20.6.2.1201 NMAC requires any person proposing a new or changed water contaminant discharge or injecting fluids (unless into a community sewer or under Liquid Waste Disposal regs) to file an NOI identifying the discharger, address, discharge location, contaminant concentrations and quantity; the department will then advise whether a discharge permit is required. The section aggregates Pueblo-specific procedures—who must receive concurrent or near-concurrent copies of NOIs/NOTs and PDMPs, timing (typically immediate or within three business days, with some two‑day or 10‑day rules), contact emails/addresses, and special restrictions (e.g., Isleta’s pesticide bans and more stringent thresholds). Footnotes clarify human-health/fish-tissue criterion assumptions, use of MCLs/background levels, 1×10^-6 carcinogen risk basis, and sediment/tissue monitoring triggers; some pueblos (Taos, Pojoaque) have no additional NOI requirements.

Permittees must provide the Pawnee Nation Department of Environmental Conservation and Safety (DECS) copies of the Notice of Intent (NOI) and Notice of Termination (NOT) at the same time they are submitted to EPA (P.O. Box 470, Pawnee, OK 74058 or dnrs@pawneenation.org). An electronic copy of the Pesticide Discharge Management Plan (PDMP) must also be submitted concurrently, and DECS must be notified immediately of any noncompliance at 918.762.3655; these requirements allow DECS to inspect and verify compliance with 40 CFR 121.11(a) and Pawnee Nation Title XII water protection statutes.

For Indian Country within the State of Texas, Condition #6 (Notice of Intent Requirements) states there are no additional requirements—no extra NOI actions or provisions apply beyond the standard permit conditions.

For Indian Country in Iowa (Meskwaki Nation), decision-makers who must submit a Notice of Intent (NOI) to EPA are required to provide a copy of the NOI to the Meskwaki Environmental Department prior to any pesticide application within the exterior boundaries of the Meskwaki Settlement.

For Indian Country within the State of Kansas (EPA Region 7), there are no additional or state-specific permit conditions — the section specifies that no further requirements apply beyond the general permit provisions.

This subsection addresses permit conditions for Indian Country within Nebraska (except Pine Ridge Reservation, which is covered in Region 8). It lists the Winnebago Tribe of Nebraska and specifies that there are no additional permit requirements for that tribe.

Covers Indian Country in Colorado and the portion of the Ute Mountain Reservation in New Mexico for EPA Region 8. For the Southern Ute Indian Tribe, pesticide applications are not eligible for discharge coverage under this permit—contact EPA Region 8 to apply for an individual permit; the Ute Mountain Ute Tribe has no additional requirements.

This section lists tribe‑specific permit conditions: in Region 8 most Indian Country (MT, ND, SD, UT, WY) have no additional requirements except the Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes, which request mailed or emailed NOIs. In Region 9 the Navajo Nation requires courtesy copies of NOIs to Navajo EPA and allows Navajo EPA inspections; several California tribes (Hoopa, Kletsel Dehe Wintun, Morongo, Big Pine Paiute) are not eligible for the general pesticide permit and must seek individual permits, while Twenty‑Nine Palms requires written NOI notification, Tribal Water Quality Standards review, and 24‑hour incident reporting; Table Mountain and La Posta have no additional requirements.
Guam has no additional permit requirements beyond the general provisions—users should consult Part 1.5 and Part 9.0 for the applicable permit conditions and guidance.

States that the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands and Indian Country within the State of Nevada (including Duck Valley Reservation in Idaho, Fort McDermitt Reservation in Oregon, and the Confederated Tribes of the Goshute Reservation in Utah) have no additional permit requirements beyond the general conditions.

Defines key terms for EPA Region 10 permit conditions: “Project Proponent” refers to those seeking coverage under the general permit, including their agents, assignees, and contractors; the “Federal Agency” is the U.S. EPA, which enforces the permit and ensures the Project Proponent’s compliance at all times.

EPA Region 10 (Washington) water-quality permit conditions enumerate approved active ingredients and site-specific restrictions for mosquito control, aquatic weed/algae management, invasive species, fish and insect control, including bans (e.g., malathion/naled in vulnerable areas), littoral-zone treatment caps by lake size, and DO monitoring requirements. The section also requires licensed applicators, permit coverage/NOI, consultation with WDFW/DNR/WSDA (timing windows and species maps), public notice/signing, and water-rights notification/replacement-water procedures, with authority citations to relevant RCW/WAC provisions.

Specifies that the certification remains valid through the pesticide general NPDES permit’s expiration date—including any administrative extensions or termination—and outlines the timing requirements for when certifications, notifications, and compliance actions take effect or must be submitted under EPA Region 10.

Project proponents must comply with Pesticide General NPDES permit reporting/notification requirements, including reporting to Washington Department of Ecology; the section explains the 30‑day appeal process to the Pollution Control Hearings Board (filing/serving details and addresses) and provides Ecology contact information and links to relevant RCW/WAC. It also summarizes Indian Country rules in Washington—most tribes impose no extra requirements, but Lummi, Makah, and Jamestown S'Klallam have specific notification, permitting, or timing requirements.

This section provides regulatory definitions used in the PGP, including terms such as Action Area, Action Threshold, Active Ingredient, Adverse Incident (with examples of non‑target effects), Water Quality Standards, and Wetlands. It’s useful for users searching for precise meanings of pesticide‑related terms, reporting criteria for adverse incidents, and environmental protection terms referenced in permit conditions.

Appendix A.2 provides a table of abbreviations and acronyms used in Section 9.0 (permit conditions for states, territories, and Indian Country), listing common environmental statutes, agencies, permit/program names, reporting tools, and technical terms that users are likely to search for (e.g., EPA, NPDES, CWA, NEPA, CERCLA, FIFRA, NOI/NOT, NeT).

Provides the Appendix D Notice of Intent form and instructions for seeking coverage under EPA’s Pesticide General Permit, including where/how to file (NeT or EPA mailing/overnight addresses if waived), required sections (A–F) collecting operator/pest management area details, and attachments. Highlights key compliance needs: PDMP for large entities, ESA eligibility documentation and mapping, Tier 3/impaired waters disclosures, timelines for submission/authorization, and certification/signature rules.

Appendix E is the EPA Notice of Termination (NOT) form used to end coverage under the Pesticide General Permit (PGP) for discharges from pesticide application. It contains the official form fields and instructions for operators to provide facility/contact information, reason and effective date of termination, certification/signature, and submission procedures to EPA or the appropriate permitting authority.

Operators may use a paper Notice of Termination only if an EPA Regional Office grants an electronic submission waiver (e.g., underserved broadband area or limited computer access) and the waiver type, EPA staff person, and approval date are recorded on the form. If waived, submit the original ink‑signed paper NOT (no copies or faxes) to the EPA Office of Water at the specified US Mail or overnight addresses; otherwise file via EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool (NeT). NOTs must be filed within 30 days after qualifying termination conditions are met.

This section presents the EPA Pesticide Discharge Evaluation Worksheet (PDEW) for small-entity Operators who are Decision-makers filing a Notice of Intent under the PGP, specifying who must complete it and timing requirements (Section B before application; remaining entries within 14 days of first application; final totals and end date within 14 days after project end) and 3-year retention. It summarizes required entries in Sections A–D: operator and treatment-area identification, pest justification and prior control measures, detailed pesticide application records (products, EPA registration numbers, quantities, methods, visual monitoring and observed adverse effects), and mandatory certified signature, plus the Paperwork Reduction Act burden notice.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > UNI: This section contains the EPA Annual Reporting Form for the Pesticide General Permit (PGP), required of any Operator who is a Decision-maker and must submit a Notice of Intent (NOI). The annual report covers all permit-covered pesticide application activities from the previous calendar year (per Part 7 of the permit) and must be submitted by February 15; form OMB No. 2040-0004 is referenced.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > **A: Explains the process for obtaining and documenting an EPA Regional Office waiver to file a paper Annual Report instead of using NetT, lists mailing and overnight addresses for submitting original paper reports with an ink signature, and provides NPDES eReporting contact info. Specifies who must file (Decision‑makers/NOI holders), the February 15 annual due date, required contents of Sections A–D (permit/contact info, adverse incidents and corrective actions, detailed pest management area entries, and authorized official certification), and notes the Paperwork Reduction Act reporting burden (8 hours).
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > UNI: Template and instructions for the Pesticide General Permit (PGP) 30-day adverse-incident written report: who must file and when (submit to EPA Region and state within 30 days after a reportable incident), required content copied from the 24-hour notification (caller/operator contact, incident location, narrative of discovery, pesticides used with EPA Reg. Nos., affected non-target organisms, cleanup/remedial actions, lab test timelines), EPA contact/date/time and any guidance received, signer certification rules and penalties, exceptions to reporting, and filing/agency notification details including endangered species contacts.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > App: This section explains the PGP Eligibility Worksheet steps used to assess pesticide actions: submitting and reviewing a Notice of Intent, determining whether Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) or National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) listed resources are in the action area, evaluating eligibility under Criteria B, C, D and F, assessing whether avoidance or mitigation measures can prevent adverse effects, and handling declared pest emergency situations.

Decision-makers must meet one of six ESA eligibility criteria (A or C–G) for coverage under the 2026 PGP; if none apply, coverage is not available. Step 1 of the worksheet is required to identify any FWS/NMFS listed species or critical habitat in the Project Action Area using EPA’s geospatial mapping tool and approved Service data (e.g., IPaC), noting NMFS handles marine/estuarine species, and the worksheet defines key terms and warns that ESA Section 9 prohibits unlawful take.

If discharges may expose ESA-listed species and you meet Criteria C–G you must submit a Notice of Intent (NOI); if you can document no exposure, submit an NOI only if otherwise required and indicate Criterion A. After NOI submittal the Services have 30 days to advise EPA whether the planned discharge meets the selected criterion, requires additional conditions, or does not meet it; EPA may place a hold, require an individual NPDES permit, or authorize the discharge (silence after 30 days implies authorization). For Declared Pest Emergencies follow pre-notification/coordination and then submit an NOI under Criterion G, and you must reevaluate/update your NOI if your proposed discharges or activities change (see Tables 1‑1 and 1‑3).

Worksheet to determine ESA eligibility for each pest management area under the 2026 PGP—select one Criterion (A–G) and provide required documentation with your NOI. Key steps: use EPA’s geospatial tool to define the Project Action Area and list species/habitats (Step 1); then follow criterion-specific requirements (e.g., Section 7 biological opinions/concurrences or Section 10 permits, written coordination or self-certifications, and special G emergency timelines) and attach maps, consultation/permit IDs, and correspondence as required.
section_summaries.PESTICIDE GENERAL PERMIT (PGP) FOR DISCH: The Pesticide General Permit authorizes Operators of point-source discharges from pesticide applications that meet Part 1.1 and are in areas listed in Appendix C to discharge to U.S. waters under the Clean Water Act, subject to permit conditions in Parts 1–9 and Appendices A–I. The permit is effective October 31, 2026, expires October 30, 2031, and currently exists as a pre-publication document (signed Dec 10, 2024) pending official Federal Register publication (Docket No. EPA-HQ-OW-2023-0268).
section_summaries.Appendices > 1.0 Coverage Under This Per: Defines who is covered by the permit—Operators meeting Part 1.1 eligibility, applicable Part 9 state/tribal requirements, and who must submit an NOI when required. 'Operator' (per Appendix A) includes Applicators (perform/day-to-day control of pesticide applications) and Decision-makers (control the decision to apply); multiple Operators can share responsibility for a single discharge, and any Operator who is both must meet all applicable requirements. NOIs are required for discharges overlapping FWS/NMFS-listed resources (see Part 1.1.2.4, Table 1-1, and Appendix I).
section_summaries.Appendices > 1.4 Severability: This severability clause states that if any part of the permit is invalidated, the rest remains in effect to the fullest extent possible. The permit continues unless EPA issues a written statement indicating that the invalidation should void additional provisions or the whole permit.
section_summaries.Appendices > 1.5 Other Federal and State: Operators must follow all applicable federal and state (including territorial) laws for pesticide applications, especially FIFRA requirements to use pesticides consistent with label directions and monitoring obligations that protect water supplies. Violating FIFRA (for example, exceeding label rates) can also violate this permit and the CWA, and other regulations (such as U.S. Coast Guard rules) may apply to covered activities.
section_summaries.Appendices > 1.6 Federally-Listed Endang: Operators must comply with any existing ESA-related conditions or requirements (from Section 7 consultations or Section 10 permits issued by FWS/NMFS) that address discharges from activities covered by this permit. These pre-existing federal actions and their protections for federally-listed endangered/threatened species and designated critical habitat remain binding on permit-covered discharges.
section_summaries.2.0 Technology-Based Effluent Limitation: Applicators must implement Part 2.1 to minimize pesticide discharges to U.S. waters by following required Pest Management Measures. Required actions include using only the amount and frequency needed (unless set by a Decision-maker), maintaining and calibrating application equipment to prevent leaks or spills, and assessing weather conditions (temperature, precipitation, wind) to ensure applications comply with federal requirements.

All Decision-makers must implement Part 2.2 to minimize pesticide discharges to U.S. waters using Pest Management Measures; those required to submit a Notice of Intent (NOI) have additional tasks. Before the first (and annually) they must identify pest management areas and target pests, set pest- and site-specific action thresholds, evaluate and preferentially use non-chemical controls (and larvicides for mosquitoes), and conduct representative pre-application surveillance—applying pesticides only when thresholds are met; subsections cover specific requirements for mosquitoes/flying insects, weeds/algae, animal pests, and forest canopy pests.
section_summaries.4.0 Monitoring > 4.1 Visual Monitoring R: Applicators must, when safety and feasibility allow, visually assess the area and surroundings during any permitted pesticide discharge for observable adverse incidents (e.g., unexpected death/distress of non-target organisms, disruption of wildlife habitat or recreational/municipal water uses). Monitoring must be documented per Part 4.3, and EPA may require additional monitoring under Part 4.4.
section_summaries.4.0 Monitoring > 4.2 Visual Monitoring R: Operators must conduct visual post-application surveillance of the treated area for observable adverse incidents (per Appendix A)—including unanticipated death/distress of non-target organisms, habitat disruption, or impacts to recreational/municipal water use—and document monitoring as required in Part 4.3. EPA may mandate additional monitoring under Part 4.4.
section_summaries.4.0 Monitoring > 4.3 Documentation of Vi: Requires For‑Hire Applicators and Decision‑makers who must file an NOI to document the findings of each visual monitoring event—or explicitly record the reason no visual monitoring was conducted—per Parts 7.2, 7.3, and 7.4. Documentation must therefore include either monitoring results or justification for omission to satisfy recordkeeping requirements.
section_summaries.4.0 Monitoring > 4.4 Additional Monitori: EPA may require additional monitoring to ensure compliance with Part 2 and/or Part 3 and will notify the Operator when such monitoring is needed. The notice will summarize the reasons and specify monitoring locations, parameters, sampling frequency and period, sample types, and reporting requirements.
section_summaries.5.0 Pesticide Discharge Management Plan: This section lists the mandatory PDMP contents: a named PDMP team with responsibilities and contact information; problem identification (target pests, sources, data, action thresholds, and site/water maps); evaluation of pest management options (including non-chemical methods and water-quality impacts); response procedures for spills and adverse incidents (containment, cleanup, training, equipment, notifications) and visual monitoring plans; preservation of documentation supporting eligibility under other federal laws (e.g., Endangered Species Act); and required authorized signature, date, and certification per 40 CFR 122.41(k).

Decision-makers must update the PDMP whenever Part 6.1 corrective-action triggers occur or when pest control changes significantly alter pollutant types/quantities. Revisions should be made before the next pesticide application that causes a discharge if practicable, or within 90 days of the change, must be signed/dated per 40 CFR 122.41(k), and an updated PDMP submitted to EPA within 15 business days.

Decision-makers must submit the Pesticide Discharge Management Plan (PDMP) and supporting documents with their NOI, retain copies, and provide them to state, Tribal, or local agencies or representatives of the Services on request. The PDMP and supporting information will be posted on EPA’s website with the NOI. Confidential Business Information (CBI) can be withheld from the public if properly claimed under 40 CFR Part 2, but must be submitted to EPA and may be shared with EPA, FWS, and NMFS staff cleared for CBI review.
section_summaries.6.0 Corrective Action > 6.1 Situations R: Operators must review and, if necessary, revise Pest Management Measures (per Parts 2.1/2.2) when specific triggers occur: an unauthorized pesticide release, EPA or operator determinations that measures are inadequate to meet Part 3 limits, monitoring showing failure to meet Part 2 effluent limits, inspections/evaluations requiring changes, or any adverse incident defined in Appendix A.
section_summaries.6.0 Corrective Action > 6.2 Corrective A: If an Operator determines changes to Pest Management Measures are needed to eliminate a condition from Part 6.1, those changes must be implemented before the next pesticide application that will cause a discharge; if that is not practicable, they must be made as soon as possible after that application.
section_summaries.6.0 Corrective Action > 6.3 Effect of Co: Correcting a condition identified under Part 6.1 does not eliminate operator liability for the original permit violation, and failing to comply with Part 6.2 is an additional violation. EPA may impose additional or more stringent requirements, schedules, and information submittal obligations related to corrective action, and such EPA-imposed requirements will supersede Parts 6.1 and 6.2 if they conflict.
section_summaries.6.0 Corrective Action > 6.6 Other Correc: For non-adverse and non-reportable situations requiring corrective action, Operators must document the triggering condition and planned corrective actions within 30 days and retain the record. Documentation must identify the condition (including any ambient water quality monitoring), describe the situation and how/when it was discovered, give dates, summarize actions taken or planned with timelines, and note measures to prevent recurrence, including any required PDMP modifications.
section_summaries.7.0 Recordkeeping and Annual Reporting >: All operators must retain copies of Adverse Incident Reports, the rationale for any decision not to report a identified adverse incident (per Part 6.4.1.2), corrective action documentation (Part 6.6), and records of spills, leaks, or other unpermitted discharges (Part 6.5.2). These records support compliance with the reporting and remediation requirements referenced in Parts 6.4–6.6.

For-hire applicators must retain equipment calibration documentation and detailed records for each treatment area, including a map/description with location and size and identification of any waters receiving discharge. Records must also include pesticide use pattern and target pest, product name(s) with EPA registration number, quantity applied, application dates, and whether visual monitoring was done (if not, why) plus any observed adverse incidents; if monitoring occurred include date, time, and location.

Decision-makers defined as small entities who must submit an NOI must retain records at the NOI address, including the submitted NOI, EPA correspondence/acknowledgement, and calibration records (if also the applicator). For each treatment area they must document location/size/maps, waters affected, pesticide use pattern, target pests and justification, prior pest management measures, applicator contact, product names with EPA registration numbers, quantities, application start/end dates, and visual monitoring details; a Pesticide Discharge Evaluation Worksheet is provided in Appendix F.

Any Decision-maker defined as a large entity who must submit an NOI must retain at the NOI-listed address copies of the NOI, EPA correspondence and acknowledgment, the PDMP (and modifications), annual reports, and calibration records if also the applicator. They must also keep detailed records for each treatment area—maps/descriptions and size, waters affected, pesticide use patterns, target pests and justification, action thresholds and supporting data, prior pest management measures, applicator contact, pesticide product names and EPA registration numbers, quantities and application dates, and whether and where visual monitoring was conducted (with findings).

Operators must document required pesticide-application records as soon as possible and no later than 14 days after each application, retain those records for at least 3 years after their permit coverage ends or is terminated, and make records available to EPA (and provide copies) upon request.

Decision-makers defined as large entities who must submit an NOI must file an annual report to EPA (electronically via NeT unless waived) by February 15 for the prior calendar year and must continue yearly while covered; special rules apply for first partial-year threshold exceedances and for reporting through permit termination. The report must include monitoring records and, for each treatment area, maps/geospatial data and size, applicator identity, total pesticide amounts by EPA registration number and application method, dates of any discharges affecting listed resources, adverse incidents, corrective actions (including spill responses), copies of visual monitoring records, and whether the activity was addressed in the PDMP.

Small-entity Decision-makers with discharges to waters of the United States and/or discharge-related activities that may expose FWS or NMFS Listed Resources of Concern must submit an annual report to EPA (via NPDES eReporting Tool/NeT unless waived) by February 15 for the prior calendar year and include monitoring records. Reports must include Decision-maker and contact info, NPDES tracking numbers, and for each treatment area a map/geospatial data (if available), location/size, identification of receiving waters, and pesticide use patterns; a prorated report is required for years when permit coverage is terminated mid-year.

Decision-makers must file NOIs, NOTs, and annual reports electronically unless they obtain a written waiver from the appropriate EPA Regional Office. Waivers are granted only for documented underserved broadband areas or limited computer access/capability; requests must include which exemption applies, supporting evidence, and a completed NOI, with Regional Office contacts listed in Part 8.2.
section_summaries.9.0 Permit Conditions Applicable Within: For EPA Region 2 Indian Country in New York: the St. Regis Mohawk Tribe has no additional permit conditions. The Seneca Nation requires electronic copies of NOIs and NOTs to its EPD within three business days (epd@sni.org or mailed to Seneca Nation EPD, 12837 Route 438, Irving, NY), may request permit access to evaluate water quality standards impacts, and requires PDMPs be submitted electronically at least 10 days before pesticide application; legal citations are provided. The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico has no territory-specific permit conditions.

Lists permit conditions for Indian Country in EPA Region 4—Alabama, Florida (Miccosukee and Seminole Tribes), Mississippi, and North Carolina (Eastern Band of Cherokee)—and states that there are no additional permit requirements for these areas.

Region 5 Indian Country conditions: Keweenaw Bay (MI) and Red Lake Nation (MN) have no additional requirements, while Fond du Lac and Leech Lake (MN) and several WI tribes (Lac du Flambeau, Bad River, Sokaogon) are not eligible for this general permit and must contact EPA Region 5 for individual permits. The Grand Portage Band (MN) imposes detailed restrictions—PGPs are denied in a Lake Superior no‑discharge/ORVW zone, cultural/wild rice protections apply, permittees must comply with tribal water quality standards, submit a Pesticide Discharge Management Plan with the NOI, may be required to monitor, report spills, and are subject to Board enforcement and tribal court appeals.

EPA will add a Part 9 comment to the Final PGP requiring operators to comply with the New Mexico Pesticide Control Act (NMSA 1978 §§76-4-1 to -39) and related NMAC rules administered by the New Mexico Department of Agriculture. The section notes NMDA authority and key compliance areas operators may be searched for: licensing/certification and fees, grounds for license actions, recordkeeping, equipment inspection, storage/disposal, continuing education, and controls on restricted‑use pesticides (see NMDA pesticide compliance guidance).

Condition #2 bars permit coverage for pesticide discharges to Tier 3 Outstanding Natural Resource Waters (ONRWs) in New Mexico except for narrowly defined restoration/maintenance (or public‑health) activities; operators must submit the NOI, project plan, and NOT to the NMED for case‑by‑case review. Operators must show any degradation will be limited in duration, minimized and controlled with BMPs, will not lower water quality below that needed to protect existing uses, and will not alter the essential character of the ONRW; discharges that fail these antidegradation criteria must obtain an individual permit. Contact details for the NMED Surface Water Quality Bureau are provided in the section.

Condition #3 requires operators proposing pesticide discharges to non‑ONRW surface waters for restoration or maintenance that may cause temporary/short‑term degradation to submit the NOI, project plan, and NOT to the New Mexico Environment Department Surface Water Quality Bureau for case‑by‑case review. Operators must show degradation will be time‑limited, minimized and controlled by BMPs or permit conditions, and will not lower water quality below levels needed to protect existing uses; discharges that cannot meet these antidegradation requirements must obtain an individual permit. The section also notes how general NPDES permits are evaluated for potential significant degradation under New Mexico’s antidegradation policy and EPA Region 6 guidance.

Operators covered by the permit must comply with New Mexico water quality standards by meeting the notification, monitoring, approval, and public‑notice requirements in 20.6.4.16 NMAC for planned piscicide discharges. Requirements include written notice to local political subdivisions, water planning entities, conservancy/irrigation districts and media, implementation of post‑treatment assessment monitoring in the application area, public notice before and during applications, and a detailed Notice of Intent describing the piscicide, target/non‑target species (including threatened/endangered), environmental impacts, surveys, alternatives analysis, and documentation of public comments.

Condition #5 requires operators to follow New Mexico spill and adverse-incident rules (20.6.2.1203 NMAC), including immediate notification and removal/response obligations. Operators must provide an oral report within 24 hours (emergency: 505-827-9329; non-emergency: 866-428-6535) and a written verification within one week with details on location, cause, chemicals, volume, and mitigation; the NMED Surface Water Quality Bureau (505-827-0187, swq.reporting@env.nm.gov) can advise on corrective actions.

Condition #6 requires Operators to file a Notice of Intent for pesticide discharges not covered by the permit that may affect groundwater and/or surface water with the New Mexico Environment Department Ground Water Quality Bureau and/or Surface Water Quality Bureau (contact addresses, phone numbers, and preferred emails are provided). The section also compiles Pueblo- and tribal-specific notification, delivery, timing, reporting, PDMP, and restriction requirements (some pueblos impose stricter thresholds or pesticide bans, others have no additional NOI requirements) to ensure compliance with tribal water quality standards and 20.6.2.1201 NMAC.

EPA Region 10 (Washington) permit conditions list approved aquatic pesticides and product types and impose site- and species-specific restrictions (e.g., bans on malathion/naled in vulnerable areas, methoprene limits, WDFW timing windows), littoral-zone treatment caps by waterbody size, and dissolved-oxygen monitoring/alternatives for algae/cyanobacteria treatments. The section requires licensed applicators, NOI/permit coverage, consultation with WDFW/WSDA/DNR, public notice and shoreline posting, notification and replacement water procedures for affected users, outlines limited tribal-specific requirements, and provides appeals and Ecology contact information.

This appendix reproduces the standard conditions in 40 CFR §122.41 that apply to all NPDES permits (must be incorporated expressly or by reference) and establishes the permittee’s duty to comply, enforcement grounds, and incorporation requirements. It highlights that effluent (§307) and sewage sludge (§405) standards must be met even if not yet in the permit, notes civil penalties (statutory amounts adjusted annually under 40 C.F.R. §19.4), and summarizes the elements and burden of proof for asserting an affirmative defense of upset (cause identification, proper operation, 24-hour notice, remedial measures, and contemporaneous logs).

Lists the geographic coverage and permit-location code prefixes used in the 2026 PGP where EPA (not a state) is the NPDES permitting authority—covering Indian Country, federal facilities, and lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction by EPA Region. Includes region-specific permit codes (e.g., NYG87####E, AKG87####E), noted reservation inclusions/exclusions, and cross-region assignments to help users identify applicable permit jurisdiction and search by permit code or location.

Appendix D is the paper Notice of Intent (NOI) for Pesticide General Permit coverage, describing how to submit via EPA’s NPDES eNOI Tool (NeT) or by paper only with a regional waiver (includes mailing and overnight addresses). It details required Sections A–F (operator info, pest management areas, ESA eligibility with geospatial species maps, Tier 3/impaired waters disclosures, attachments, PDMP for large entities), certification/signature rules, and submission timelines and procedures.

Appendix E provides the official EPA Notice of Termination (NOT) form and instructions for ending PGP coverage—operators must file via EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool (NeT) unless granted an EPA electronic submission waiver. It lists paper mailing and overnight addresses, filing deadlines (within 30 days of qualifying termination conditions), who must file, required form fields (permit info, operator info, certification, preparer), and certification/signature rules (original ink signature required; no copies/faxes), plus the Paperwork Reduction Act burden estimate.

Appendix F provides the Pesticide Discharge Evaluation Worksheet (PDEW) for small-entity Decision-makers filing a PGP Notice of Intent. It specifies who must complete the form, timing (Section B before application; most entries within 14 days of first application; final totals/end date within 14 days after project end), 3‑year retention, and required entries in Sections A–D (operator/treatment-area identification, pest evaluation and prior controls, detailed pesticide products/EPA registration numbers/quantities/methods, visual monitoring and observed effects, and a certified signature), plus preparer contact fields and a PRA burden notice.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > App: This appendix provides the PGP Eligibility Worksheet for determining ESA eligibility for pesticide discharges: Decision-makers must use EPA’s geospatial mapping tool (Step 1) to identify FWS/NMFS-listed species or critical habitat in the Project Action Area and then satisfy one of Criteria A or C–G to obtain coverage. It summarizes required documentation and processes for each criterion (e.g., Section 7 biological opinions or concurrence, Section 10 permits, written Service coordination, self-certifications), NOI submission and review timelines, and special procedures for Declared Pest Emergencies, plus required attachments (map, species list, consultation/permit IDs, correspondence).
section_summaries.Contents: This is the Table of Contents for the permit document, listing major sections and page locations—covering permit scope and eligibility, authorization to discharge, alternative permits, legal and species-protection requirements, permit conditions (monitoring, reporting, compliance), and EPA regional contact information.
section_summaries.Appendices: The Appendices contain reference materials and required forms to support permit compliance: definitions and acronyms, standard conditions, geographic coverage, NOI/NOT forms, reporting templates, and technical worksheets (e.g., pesticide discharge evaluation and ESA eligibility) used for filing, reporting, and demonstrating eligibility—particularly for coordination with FWS/NMFS on threatened and endangered species.
section_summaries.2.0 Technology-Based Effluent Limitation: This section establishes technology-based effluent limits for pesticide discharges, defines Applicator and Decision-maker duties, and requires Decision-makers who file an NOI to annually and before each season identify pest areas/targets, set pest- and site-specific action thresholds, evaluate non-chemical controls (and larvicides for mosquitoes), and perform representative pre-application surveillance—applying pesticides only when thresholds are met. Applicators must implement required pest management measures, use minimal amounts/frequencies, maintain and calibrate equipment, assess weather to avoid off-target discharges, and comply with all applicable laws.
section_summaries.3.0 Water Quality-Based Effluent Limitat: Sets water-quality-based effluent limitations for pesticide discharges, prohibiting observable floating solids, scum, sheen, oil/grease films, foam, or color/odor changes beyond what would be expected from FIFRA-labeled application. Prohibits discharging to waters listed as impaired by an active ingredient or its degradate and to waters designated Tier 3 (Outstanding National Resource Waters) except as allowed elsewhere in the permit. Operators must comply upon beginning discharge and must take corrective actions — up to ceasing discharge — if violations are identified.
section_summaries.5.0 Pesticide Discharge Management Plan: Large entities required to file a Notice of Intent (NOI) must prepare and submit a Pesticide Discharge Management Plan (PDMP) with the NOI that documents the PDMP team, problem identification and action thresholds, evaluation of pest management measures (including non-chemical options), spill and adverse-incident response and visual monitoring procedures, and required ESA/other federal-law eligibility documentation. The PDMP must be signed/certified per 40 CFR 122.41(k), updated when corrective-action triggers or major pest-control changes occur (practicably before the next discharge or within 90 days), submitted/posted with the NOI, and may withhold properly claimed CBI from public posting.
section_summaries.6.0 Corrective Action: Operators must phone EPA within 24 hours of any adverse incident (with a 30-day written follow-up to EPA/state/Tribal leads), immediately notify NMFS or FWS if listed species or critical habitat are affected, and call the National Response Center for spills meeting reportable quantities. Corrective actions and PDMP revisions are required when specified triggers occur and must be implemented before the next discharge (or ASAP), documented and retained (typically 30 days); reporting by one authorized operator can satisfy all co-operators, but corrective action does not remove liability for the original violation.
section_summaries.7.0 Recordkeeping and Annual Reporting: All Operators must keep accurate pesticide-discharge records, with additional, more detailed requirements for for-hire applicators and Decision-makers who must submit NOIs (different sets for small vs. large entities). Required records include treatment area maps/locations and sizes, receiving waters, pesticide product names and EPA registration numbers, quantities and dates applied, monitoring/visual inspection results, adverse-incident and corrective-action documentation, and PDMP materials where applicable; records must be documented promptly (within 14 days) and retained at least 3 years after permit coverage ends. Large-entity Decision-makers (and certain small entities with discharges to U.S. waters or listed resources) must file annual reports by Feb 15 via NeT/eReporting unless granted a written waiver for limited access.
section_summaries.8.0 EPA Contact Information and Mailing: Specifies that NOIs, NOTs, and annual reports must be submitted via EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool (NeT) unless unavailable or waived, and that adverse-incident reports must be sent within 30 days to the appropriate EPA Regional office and state/tribal pesticide lead agency. Provides USPS and overnight/express addresses for EPA Headquarters and detailed Water Division mailing/contact addresses for EPA Regions 1–10, including notes on covered states, tribal reservations, and special jurisdictional exceptions.
section_summaries.9.0 Permit Conditions Applicable Within: Section 9.0 lists modifications and additions to the Pesticide General Permit that apply only in specified states, territories, Indian Country, and federal facilities — including tribal notification and PDMP requirements, detailed procedures for filing NOIs/NOTs and completing the PDEW, and regional lists of approved active ingredients and use restrictions (notably extensive Washington/Region 10 conditions). It also provides EPA permit-location codes by region, state antidegradation/ONRW and spill‑reporting requirements (e.g., New Mexico), and appeals, contact, and submission addresses users will search for.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template: Appendix G contains the EPA Annual Report form and instructions for PGP operators (Decision‑makers/NOI holders), requiring submission via NPDES eReporting Tool (NetT) unless an EPA Regional waiver permits original ink‑signed paper filings to specified addresses; annual reports are due February 15 and must include Sections A–D (contact/permit info, adverse incidents/corrective actions, pest management area details, and authorized‑official certification). The appendix also includes the 30‑day adverse incident written‑report template and filing timelines, ESA eligibility worksheet guidance (use EPA’s geospatial mapping tool and provide documentation for Criteria A, C–G), NPDES eReporting/helpdesk contacts, and Paperwork Reduction Act burden estimates (8 hours annual, 4 hours 30‑day).

chunks.content: **PRE-PUBLICATION NOTICE.** All 10 U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Regions signed the following document on December 10, 2024, and EPA is submitting it for publication in the Federal Register (FR). This document is not disseminated for purposes of EPA's Information Quality Guidelines and does not represent an Agency determination or policy. While we have taken steps to ensure the accuracy of this Internet version of the document, it is not the official version. Please refer to the official version in a forthcoming FR publication, which will appear on the Government Printing Office's govinfo website (<https://www.govinfo.gov/app/collection/fr>). It will also appear on Regulations.gov (<https://www.regulations.gov>) in Docket No. EPA-HQ-OW-2023-0268. Once the official version of this document is published in the FR, this version will be removed from the internet and replaced with a link to the official version.

header_path.name: Appendices

chunks.content:
This permit covers any Operator who meets the eligibility requirements identified in Part 1.1, requirements in Part 9 imposed by applicable states (including territories) or Tribes, and if so required, has submitted a Notice of Intent (NOI) in accordance with Part 1.2.

Note: All Operators with discharges covered by this permit and discharge-related activities that overlap with U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) or National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) Listed Resources of Concern are required to submit an NOI. See Part 1.1.2.4, Table 1-1, and Appendix I for the information Decision-maker must submit with their NOI and for Endangered Species Act (ESA) eligibility criteria that must be met.

header_path.name: Appendices
1.0 Coverage Under This Permit

chunks.content: For the purpose of this permit, “Operator” is defined in Appendix A to mean any entity associated with the application of pesticides which results in a discharge to waters of the United States that meets either of the following two criteria: (1) any entity who performs the application of a pesticide or who has day-to-day control of the application (*i.e.*, they are authorized to direct workers to carry out those activities); or (2) any entity with control over the decision to perform pesticide applications including the ability to modify those decisions. Operators identified in (1) above are referred to in this permit as Applicators while Operators identified in (2) are referred to in this permit as Decision-makers. As defined, more than one Operator may be responsible for complying with this permit for any single discharge from the application of pesticides.

header_path.name: Appendices
1.0 Coverage Under This Permit

chunks.content:
For purposes of this permit, all Operators are defined as either an Applicator or a Decision-maker or both an Applicator and a Decision-maker.

When an Operator is both an Applicator and a Decision-maker, the Operator must comply with all applicable requirements imposed on both Applicators and Decision-makers. When the permit references all “Operators,” both Applicators and Decision-makers must comply.

header_path.name: Appendices
1.0 Coverage Under This Permit

chunks.content:
This permit is available to Operators who discharge to waters of the United States from the application of (1) biological pesticides or (2) chemical pesticides that leave a residue (collectively called *pesticides*), when the pesticide application is for one of the following pesticide use patterns:

- a. **Mosquito and Other Flying Insect Pest Control**—to control public health/nuisance and other flying insect pests that develop or are present during a portion of their life cycle in or above standing or flowing water. Public health/nuisance and other flying insect pests in this use category include mosquitoes and black flies.
- b. **Weed and Algae Pest Control**—to control weeds, algae, and pathogens that are pests in water and at water’s edge, including ditches and/or canals.
- c. **Animal Pest Control**—to control animal pests in water and at water’s edge. Animal pests in this use category include fish, lampreys, insects, mollusks, and pathogens.

header_path.name: Appendices
1.1 Eligibility
1.1.1 Activities Covered

chunks.content: d. **Forest Canopy Pest Control**—application of a pesticide to a forest canopy to control the population of a pest species (e.g., insect or pathogen) where, to target the pests effectively, a portion of the pesticide unavoidably will be applied over and deposited to water.

header_path.name: Appendices
1.1 Eligibility
1.1.1 Activities Covered

chunks.content: Operators are not eligible for coverage under this permit for any discharges from a pesticide application to waters of the United States if the water is identified as impaired by a substance which either is an active ingredient in that pesticide or is a degradate of such an active ingredient.

header_path.name: Appendices
1.1 Eligibility
1.1.2 Limitations on Coverage
1.1.2.1 *Discharges to Water Quality Impaired Waters*

chunks.content: For purposes of this permit, impaired waters are those that have been identified by a state, Tribe, or EPA pursuant to Section 303(d) of the CWA as not meeting applicable state or tribal water quality standards. Impaired waters, for the purposes of this permit, consist of both waters with EPA-approved or EPA-established total maximum daily loads (TMDLs) and waters for which EPA has not yet approved or established a TMDL. A list of those waters is available at <https://www.epa.gov/tmdl/>. If a discharge from a pesticide application would not be eligible under this permit because the water is listed as impaired for that specific pesticide, but there is evidence that shows the water is no longer impaired, Operators may submit this information to EPA consistent with Table 1-2 in Part 1.2.3, and request that coverage be allowed under this permit.

header_path.name: Appendices
1.1 Eligibility
1.1.2 Limitations on Coverage
1.1.2.1 *Discharges to Water Quality Impaired Waters*

chunks.content: Except for discharges from pesticide applications made to restore or maintain water quality or to protect public health or the environment that either do not degrade water quality or only degrade water quality on a short-term or temporary basis, Operators are not eligible for coverage under this permit for discharges to waters of the United States if the water is designated by a state or Tribe as Tier 3 (Outstanding National Resource Waters) for antidegradation purposes under Title 40 of the *Code of Federal Regulations* (CFR) 131.12(a)(3). A list of Tier 3 waters is available on EPA's website at <https://www.epa.gov/npdes/pesticide-permitting>.

header_path.name: Appendices
1.1 Eligibility
1.1.2 Limitations on Coverage
1.1.2.2 *Discharges to Waters Designated as Tier 3 for Antidegradation Purposes*

chunks.content:
Discharges are not eligible for coverage under this permit if any of the following circumstances apply:

- The discharge is covered by another NPDES permit, or
- The discharge was included in a permit that in the past 5 years has been or is in the process of being denied, terminated, or revoked by EPA (this does not apply to the routine reissuance of permits every 5 years).

header_path.name: Appendices
1.1 Eligibility
1.1.2 Limitations on Coverage
1.1.2.3 *Discharges Currently or Previously Covered by Another Permit*

chunks.content: Coverage under this permit is available only for discharges to waters of the United States and discharge-related activities that meet one of the ESA eligibility criteria (A through G)

header_path.name: Appendices
1.1 Eligibility
1.1.2 Limitations on Coverage
1.1.2.4 *Endangered and Threatened Species and Critical Habitat Protection*

chunks.content: identified below. EPA’s geospatial mapping tool<sup>1</sup> at <https://www.epa.gov/npdes/pesticide-permitting-ESA-procedures> must be used to determine whether ESA-listed species and/or designated critical habitat (Listed Resources of Concern) may be exposed to pollutants in the Project Action Area(s) as a result of pesticide applications made to the pest management area(s). The tool will provide a resource list and map identifying whether, where, and which FWS Listed Resources of Concern and NMFS Listed Resources of Concern may be present in the Project Action Area.

header_path.name: Appendices
1.1 Eligibility
1.1.2 Limitations on Coverage
1.1.2.4 *Endangered and Threatened Species and Critical Habitat Protection*

chunks.content: Activities that meet one of the ESA eligibility criteria (A through G) are not likely to result in any short- or long-term adverse effects to species that are federally-listed as endangered or threatened (“listed”) under the Endangered Species Act (ESA) or habitat that is federally-designated as critical under the ESA (“critical habitat”), except as provided in eligibility Criteria C, D, and, for 60 days, G. Under Criteria C and D, effects to listed species and critical habitat have already been addressed through a separate Section 10 permit, or Section 7(a)(2) consultation. Under Criterion G, effects to listed species and critical habitat have already been addressed through the coordination with the Services.

header_path.name: Appendices
1.1 Eligibility
1.1.2 Limitations on Coverage
1.1.2.4 *Endangered and Threatened Species and Critical Habitat Protection*

chunks.content: As one of the provisions in this permit that help limit adverse effects to these resources, the six eligibility criteria (A-G) relate to the impacts a prospective discharger’s activities may have on listed species and critical habitat. Specifically, the conditions in the ESA eligibility criteria relate to potential impacts on Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) Listed Resources of Concern as defined in Appendix A and National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) Listed Resources of Concern as defined in Appendix A. These are resources that have been identified through consultation with FWS and NMFS on the PGP as having potential exposure to pesticides from discharges and discharge-related activities that warrant the additional protections entailed in compliance with eligibility criteria A-G. Other provisions that protect listed species more broadly include Part 1.6, which requires compliance with any conditions resulting from an ESA Section 7 consultation or ESA Section 10 permit; Part 6.4.3,

header_path.name: Appendices
1.1 Eligibility
1.1.2 Limitations on Coverage
1.1.2.4 *Endangered and Threatened Species and Critical Habitat Protection*

chunks.content: provisions that protect listed species more broadly include Part 1.6, which requires compliance with any conditions resulting from an ESA Section 7 consultation or ESA Section 10 permit; Part 6.4.3, which requires notification for an adverse incident to threatened or endangered species or critical habitat; and the waiting period between NOI submittal and authorization to discharge, which provides an opportunity for the Services, EPA, and members of the public to identify any potential impacts on listed species and critical habitat, and for EPA to notify the permittee if further conditions or an individual permit are necessary.

chunks.content:
To be eligible for coverage under this permit, Decision-makers must meet one of the following six eligibility criteria (A-G) for the entire term of coverage under the permit and, if required to submit an NOI, are required to provide the supporting documentation with the NOI:

**Criterion A.** Pesticide application activities will not result in a point source discharge to one or more waters of the United States or involve discharge-related activities that may expose FWS Listed Resources of Concern and NMFS Listed Resources of Concern to pollutants. If this pesticide application is in response to a Declared Pest Emergency Situation, see Criterion G.

**Criterion C.** Pesticide application activities for which permit coverage is being requested will discharge to one or more waters of the United States and/or involve discharge-related activities that may expose FWS Listed Resources of Concern and/or NMFS Listed Resources of Concern to pollutants, but all “take” of these resources associated with such pesticide application activities has been authorized through FWS’ and/or NMFS’ issuance of a permit under Section 10 of the ESA, and such authorization

chunks.content: addresses the effects of the pesticide discharges to waters of the United States and discharge-related activities on federally-listed species and federally-designated critical habitat based on the list of FWS Listed Resources of Concern and NMFS Listed Resources of Concern generated within 90 days of NOI submittal. (The term “take” means to harass, harm, pursue, hunt, shoot, wound, kill, trap, capture, or collect, or to attempt to engage in any such conduct. See Section 3 of the Endangered Species Act, 16 U.S.C. § 1532(19).)

See Appendix D (NOI form) and Appendix I (worksheet) for the information required under Criterion C.*

chunks.content: **Criterion D.** Pesticide application activities for which permit coverage is being requested will discharge to one or more receiving waters of the United States and/or involve discharge-related activities that may expose FWS Listed Resources of Concern and/or NMFS Listed Resources of Concern to pollutants, but consultation with FWS and/or NMFS under section 7 of the ESA has been concluded for pesticide application activities covered under this permit. Consultations can be either formal or informal and would have occurred only as a result of a separate federal action. The consultation addressed the effects of pesticide discharges to waters of the United States and discharge-related activities on federally-listed threatened or endangered species and federally-designated critical habitat based on the list of FWS Listed Resources of Concern and NMFS Listed Resources of Concern generated within 90 days of NOI submittal. The consultation must have resulted in either:

chunks.content:

A biological opinion from FWS and/or NMFS finding no jeopardy to federally-listed species and no destruction/adverse modification of federally-designated critical habitat and the Reasonable and Prudent Measures to minimize take have been or are in the process of being implemented in accordance with the biological opinion; or
- ii. Written concurrence from FWS and/or NMFS with a finding that the pesticide discharges to waters of the United States and discharge-related activities are not likely to adversely affect federally-listed species or federally-designated critical habitat.

**Criterion E.** Pesticide application activities for which permit coverage is being requested in the NOI will discharge to one or more waters of the United States and/or involve discharge-related activities that may expose FWS Listed Resources of Concern and/or NMFS Listed Resources of Concern to pollutants. Such discharges eligible under Criterion E are those where the Decision-maker includes in the NOI written correspondence from FWS and/or NMFS that pesticide application activities performed consistent with appropriate measures will avoid or eliminate the likelihood of any short- or long-term adverse effects to FWS Listed Resources of Concern and/or NMFS Listed Resources of Concern.

Such discharges eligible under criterion F are those from pesticide application activities that are demonstrated by the Decision-maker as not likely to result in any short- or long-term adverse effects to each FWS Listed Resources of Concern and NMFS Listed Resources of Concern identified in the Project Action Area.

See Appendix D (NOI form) and Appendix I (worksheet) for the information required under Criterion F.*

1.1.2 Limitations on Coverage

chunks.content: **Criterion G.** Pesticide application activities were, or will be, discharged to one or more waters of the United States in response to a Declared Pest Emergency Situation as defined in Appendix A of the PGP. Prior to any discharge to waters of the United States under Criterion G, Decision-makers must notify and begin to coordinate with FWS and NMFS. Notification shall occur and coordination shall begin as soon as possible after determining that pesticide application is required in response to a Declared Pest Emergency Situation. As part of any coordination, technical assistance or recommendations provided by the Services for avoiding any short- or long-term adverse effects during the emergency should be implemented as prescribed either before or after discharge has begun, as applicable) to be eligible for coverage under the permit. The Decision-makers must provide documentation of the coordination and written

The Decision-maker must also provide EPA with their rationale supporting the determination whether the discharge is likely to result in any short- or long-term adverse effects to FWS Listed Resources of Concern and NMFS Listed Resources of Concern, including the description of appropriate measures that have or will be undertaken to avoid or eliminate the likelihood of any short- or long-term adverse effects.

chunks.content: *Supporting documentation required with the NOI to meet this Criterion - Decision-makers are required to provide information on anticipated applications and provide a rationale for each individual listed species or designated critical habitat as to why any short- or long-term adverse effects did not occur and are not expected, and a statement verifying the notification and coordination with FWS and NMFS. The notification must be in the form of an email to FWS and/or NMFS that identifies the appropriate FWS, NMFS and EPA contact(s) and includes a description of the action, a map with geospatial data of the Project Action Area, and a list of FWS Listed Resources of Concern and NMFS Listed Resources of Concern identified in the Project Action Area or a list showing no FWS Listed Resources of Concern and NMFS Listed Resources of Concern occur in the Project Action Area. See Appendix D (NOI form) and Appendix I (worksheet) for the information required under Criterion G.*

chunks.content:
The following discharges, consistent with the permit eligibility provisions in Part 1.1, are automatically authorized by this permit beginning October 31, 2026.

- Eligible discharges that result from the application of a pesticide as part of *pesticide research and development* as defined in Appendix A. See Part 1.1.2.4 and Table 1-1 for discharges that require an NOI;
- Eligible discharges for which submission of an NOI is not required. See Parts 1.2.2 and 1.2.3.

To obtain authorization under this permit for all other eligible discharges, a Decision-maker must submit a timely, complete, and accurate NOI consistent with the requirements of Parts 1.2.2 and 1.2.3.
